revision.text:
{{short description|Regions of the ocean where the abundance of phytoplankton is low and fairly constant despite the availability of macronutrients}} '''High-nutrient, low-chlorophyll (HNLC) regions''' are regions of the ocean where the abundance of [[phytoplankton]] is low and fairly constant despite the availability of [[Macronutrient (ecology)|macronutrients]]. Phytoplankton rely on a suite of nutrients for cellular function. Macronutrients (e.g., [[nitrate]], [[phosphate]], [[silicic acid]]) are generally available in higher quantities in surface ocean waters, and are the typical components of common garden fertilizers. [[Micronutrient]]s (e.g., [[iron]], [[zinc]], [[cobalt]]) are generally available in lower quantities and include [[trace metal]]s. Macronutrients are typically available in [[Molar concentration|millimolar concentrations,]] while micronutrients are generally available in micro- to nanomolar concentrations. In general, nitrogen tends to be a [[Limiting factor|limiting ocean nutrient]], but in HNLC regions it is never significantly depleted.<ref name="lalli2">Lalli, C.M.; Parsons, T.R. (2004) ''Biological Oceanography: An Introduction'' (2nd Ed.) Elsevier Butterworth Heinemann, Burlington, MA, p. 55.</ref><ref name="pitchford3">{{cite journal | last1 = Pitchford | first1 = J.W. | last2 = Brindley | first2 = J. | year = 1999 | title = Iron limitation, grazing pressure and oceanic high-nutrient-low chlorophyll (HNLC) regions | url = | journal = Journal of Plankton Research | volume = 21 | issue = 3| pages = 525–547 | doi=10.1093/plankt/21.3.525}}</ref> Instead, these regions tend to be limited by low concentrations of metabolizable iron.<ref name="lalli2" /> Iron is a critical phytoplankton micronutrient necessary for [[enzyme catalysis]] and [[Electron transport chain|electron transport]].<ref name=":192">Venables, H., and C. M. Moore (2010), Phytoplankton and light limitation in the Southern Ocean: Learning from high-nutrient, high-chlorophyll areas, J. Geophys. Res., '''115''', C02015, doi:10.1029/2009JC005361</ref><ref name=":202">{{cite journal | last1 = Hassler | first1 = C. S. | last2 = Sinoir | first2 = M. | last3 = Clementson | first3 = L. A. | last4 = Butler | first4 = E. C. V. | year = 2012 | title = Exploring the Link between Micronutrients and Phytoplankton in the Southern Ocean during the 2007 Austral Summer | journal = Frontiers in Microbiology | volume = 3 | issue = | page = 202 | doi=10.3389/fmicb.2012.00202| pmid = 22787456 | pmc = 3392650 }}</ref>
Between the 1930s and '80s, it was hypothesized that iron is a limiting ocean micronutrient, but there were not sufficient methods to reliably detect iron in seawater to confirm this hypothesis.<ref name=":03">{{Cite book|title=Primary productivity and biogeochemical cycles in the sea|last=Martin|first=John|publisher=Springer US|year=1992|isbn=|location=|pages=122–137}}</ref> In 1989, high concentrations of iron-rich sediments in nearshore coastal waters off the Gulf of Alaska were detected.<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=John|last2=Gordon|first2=Michael|last3=Fitzwater|first3=Steve|last4=Broenkow|first4=William W.|date=1989|title=VERTEX: phytoplankton/iron studies in the Gulf of Alaska|url=|journal=Deep Sea Research Part A. Oceanographic Research Papers|volume=35 | issue = 6 |pages=649–680|via=}}</ref> However, offshore waters had lower iron concentrations and lower productivity despite macronutrient availability for phytoplankton growth.<ref name=":14"/> This pattern was observed in other oceanic regions and led to the naming of three major HNLC zones: the North [[Pacific Ocean]], the Equatorial Pacific Ocean, and the [[Southern Ocean]].<ref name="lalli2" /><ref name="pitchford3"/>
The discovery of HNLC regions has fostered scientific debate about the ethics and efficacy of iron fertilization experiments which attempt to draw down atmospheric [[carbon dioxide]] by stimulating surface-level photosynthesis. It has also led to the development of hypotheses such as grazing control which poses that HNLC regions are formed, in part, from the grazing of phytoplankton (e.g. [[dinoflagellate]]s, [[ciliate]]s) by smaller organisms (e.g. [[protist]]s).
== Primary production == {{Main article|Primary production}} [[File:Seawifs_global_biosphere_Centered_on_the_Pacific.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seawifs_global_biosphere_Centered_on_the_Pacific.jpg|thumb|383x383px|Global distribution of surface chlorophyll levels. Chlorophyll (a proxy for phytoplankton mass) is relatively low in the three HNLC regions (North Pacific, Equatorial Pacific, and Southern Ocean).]] [[File:Global_N-P_Ratio.gif|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Global_N-P_Ratio.gif|thumb|386x386px|Global nitrogen to phosphorus ratio is plotted for the global surface ocean. Nutrients are available in the three HNLC regions in sufficient RKR Ratios for biological activity.]] Primary production is the process by which [[autotroph]]s use light to convert carbon from aqueous carbon dioxide to sugar for cellular growth.<ref name=":272">{{Cite book|title=Biological oceanography|last=Miller|first=Charles B.|last2=Wheeler|first2=Patricia A.|publisher=John Wiley and Sons, Ltd.|year=2012|isbn=9781444333015|edition=2nd|location=Chichester, West Sussex|pages=49–62|oclc=794619582}}</ref> Light catalyzes the [[Photosynthesis|photosynthetic]] process and nutrients are incorporated into [[Organic matter|organic material]]. For photosynthesis to occur, macronutrients such as nitrate and phosphate must be available in sufficient ratios and [[Bioavailability|bioavailable forms]] for biological utilization. The molecular ratio of 106(Carbon):16(Nitrogen):1(Phosphorus) was discovered by [[Redfield ratio|Redfield, Ketcham, and Richards (RKR)]] and is known as the [[Redfield ratio|Redfield Ratio]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Sea|last=Redfield|first=A.C.|last2=Ketchum|first2=G.H.|last3=Richards|first3=F.A.|publisher=Wiley-Interscience|year=1963|isbn=|editor-last=Hill|editor-first=M.N.|location=New York|pages=26–77|chapter=The influence of organisms on the composition of sea water}}</ref> Photosynthesis (forward) and respiration (reverse) is represented by the equation:
:<chem>{106CO2} + {16HNO3} + {H3PO4} + {122H2O} <=> {(CH2O)106(NH3)16(H3PO4)} + {136O2}</chem><ref>{{Cite book|title=Aquatic Chemistry : Chemical Equilibria and Rates in Natural Waters.|last=Werner.|first=Stumm,|date=2013|publisher=Wiley|others=Morgan, James J.|isbn=9780471673033|edition=3rd|location=Hoboken|oclc=863203908}}</ref>
Photosynthesis can be limited by deficiencies of certain macronutrients. However, in the North Pacific, the Equatorial Pacific, and the Southern Ocean macronutrients are found in sufficient ratios, quantities and bioavailable forms to support greater levels of primary production than found. Macronutrient availability in HNLC regions in tandem with low [[Biomass (ecology)|standing stock]]s of phytoplankton suggests that some other biogeochemical process limits phytoplankton growth.<ref name=":272"/>
Since primary production and phytoplankton biomass cannot currently be measured over entire ocean basins, scientists use [[Chlorophyll a|chlorophyll α]] as a proxy for primary production. Modern satellite observations monitor and track global chlorophyll α abundances in the ocean via [[remote sensing]]. Higher chlorophyll concentrations generally indicate areas of enhanced primary production, and conversely lower chlorophyll levels indicate low primary production. This co-occurrence of low chlorophyll and high macronutrient availability is why these regions are deemed "high-nutrient, low-chlorophyll."
In addition to the macronutrients needed for organic matter synthesis, phytoplankton need micronutrients such as [[trace metal]]s for cellular functions.<ref name=":272"/> Micronutrient availability can constrain primary production because trace metals are sometimes limiting nutrients. Iron has been determined to be a primary limiting micronutrient in HNLC provinces.<ref name=":03"/> Recent studies have indicated that zinc and cobalt may be secondary and/or co-limiting micronutrients.<ref name=":42">{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/250217285|title=Iron and zinc effects on silicic acid and nitrate uptake kinetics in three high-nutrient, low-chlorophyll (HNLC) regions (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref><ref name=":262">{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=M. A.|last2=Morel|first2=F. M. M.|last3=Guillard|first3=R. R. L.|date=1978-11-02|title=Growth limitation of a coastal diatom by low zinc ion activity|url=https://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v276/n5683/abs/276070a0.html|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=276|issue=5683|pages=70–71|doi=10.1038/276070a0|bibcode=1978Natur.276...70A}}</ref>
== Global distribution ==
=== Common characteristics === HNLC regions cover 20% of the world’s oceans and are characterized by varying physical, chemical, and biological patterns. These surface waters have annually varying, yet relatively abundant macronutrient concentrations compared to other oceanic provinces.<ref name=":03"/> While HNLC broadly describes the biogeochemical trends of these large ocean regions, all three zones experience seasonal phytoplankton blooms in response to global atmospheric patterns. On average, HNLC regions tend to be growth-limited by iron and variably, zinc.<ref name=":262"/><ref name=":232">{{Cite journal|last=De La Rocha|first=Christina L.|last2=Hutchins|first2=David A.|last3=Brzezinski|first3=Mark A.|last4=Zhang|first4=Yaohong|date=2000|title=Effects of iron and zinc deficiency on elemental composition and silica production by diatoms|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|volume=195|pages=71–79|doi=10.3354/meps195071|jstor=24855011|bibcode=2000MEPS..195...71D}}</ref> This trace metal limitation leads to communities of smaller sized phytoplankton. Compared to more productive regions of the ocean, HNLC zones have higher ratios of silicic acid to nitrate because larger [[diatom]]s, that require silicic acid to make their opal silica shells, are less prevalent.<ref name=":42"/><ref name=":262" /><ref name=":232"/> Unlike the Southern Ocean and the North Pacific, the Equatorial Pacific experiences temporal silicate availability which leads to large seasonal diatom blooms.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dugdale|first=Richard C.|last2=Wilkerson|first2=Frances P.|last3=Minas|first3=Hans J.|date=1995-05-01|title=The role of a silicate pump in driving new production|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/096706379500015X|journal=Deep Sea Research Part I: Oceanographic Research Papers|volume=42|issue=5|pages=697–719|doi=10.1016/0967-0637(95)00015-X|bibcode=1995DSRI...42..697D}}</ref><ref name=":32">{{Cite journal|last=Dugdale|first=Richard C.|last2=Wilkerson|first2=Frances P.|date=1998-01-15|title=Silicate regulation of new production in the equatorial Pacific upwelling|url=https://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v391/n6664/full/391270a0.html|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=391|issue=6664|pages=270–273|doi=10.1038/34630|bibcode=1998Natur.391..270D}}</ref>
The distribution of trace metals and relative abundance of macronutrients are reflected in the plankton community structure. For example, the selection of phytoplankton with a high surface area to volume ratio results in HNLC regions being dominated by nano- and picoplankton. This ratio allows for optimal utilization of available dissolved nutrients. Larger phytoplankton, such as diatoms, cannot energetically sustain themselves in these regions. Common picoplankton within these regions include genera such as [[prochlorococcus]] (not generally found in the North Pacific), [[synechococcus]], and various [[eukaryote]]s. Grazing protists likely control the abundance and distribution of these small phytoplankton.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cullen|first=John J.|last2=Lewis|first2=Marlon R.|last3=Davis|first3=Curtiss O.|last4=Barber|first4=Richard T.|date=1992-01-15|title=Photosynthetic characteristics and estimated growth rates indicate grazing is the proximate control of primary production in the equatorial Pacific|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans|language=en|volume=97|issue=C1|pages=639–654|doi=10.1029/91JC01320|issn=2156-2202|bibcode=1992JGR....97..639C}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Landry|first=M. R.|last2=Constantinou|first2=J.|last3=Latasa|first3=M.|last4=Brown|first4=S. L.|last5=Bidigare|first5=R. R.|last6=Ondrusek|first6=M. E.|date=2000-08-09|title=Biological response to iron fertilization in the eastern equatorial Pacific (IronEx II). III. Dynamics of phytoplankton growth and microzooplankton grazing|url=http://www.int-res.com/abstracts/meps/v201/p57-72/|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|volume=201|pages=57–72|doi=10.3354/meps201057|bibcode=2000MEPS..201...57L}}</ref>
The generally lower net primary production in HNLC zones results in lower biological draw-down of atmospheric carbon dioxide and thus these regions are generally considered a net source of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere.<ref name=":32"/> HNLC areas are of interest to geoengineers and some in the scientific community who believe fertilizing large patches of these waters with iron could potentially lower dissolved carbon dioxide and offset increased anthropogenic carbon emissions.<ref name=":14"/> Analysis of Antarctic ice core data over the last million years shows correlation between high levels of dust and low temperature, indicating that addition of diffuse iron-rich dust to the sea has been a natural amplifier of climate cooling. <ref>p.15 Oeste, Franz Dietrich; Richter, Renaud de; Ming, Tingzhen; Caillol, Sylvain (2017): Climate engineering by mimicking natural dust climate control. The iron salt aerosol method. In: Earth Syst. Dynam. 8 (1), S. 1–54. DOI: 10.5194/esd-8-1-2017</ref>
=== North Pacific === [[File:Dust_storm_in_Alaska_(10929944066).jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Dust_storm_in_Alaska_(10929944066).jpg|thumb|right|Dust blown off the Alaskan coast into the North Pacific.]] [[File:North_Pacific_Subtropical_Convergence_Zone.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:North_Pacific_Subtropical_Convergence_Zone.jpg|right|thumb|400x400px|Currents in the North Pacific Ocean.]]
The discovery and naming of the first HNLC region, the North Pacific, was formalized in a seminal paper published in 1988.<ref name=":14"/> The study concluded that surface waters of the eastern North Pacific are generally dominated by picoplankton despite the relative abundance of macronutrients.<ref name=":14"/> In other words, larger phytoplankton, such as diatoms which thrive in nutrient-rich waters, were not found. Instead, the surface waters were replete with smaller pico- and nanoplankton.<ref name=":14"/> Based on laboratory nutrient experiments, iron was hypothesized to be a key limiting micronutrient.<ref name=":14"/>
The Pacific Ocean is the largest and oldest body of water on Earth. The North Pacific is characterized by the general clockwise rotation of the [[North Pacific Gyre|North Pacific gyre]], which is driven by [[trade winds]]. Spatial variations in tradewinds result in cooler air temperatures in the western North Pacific and milder air temperatures in the eastern North Pacific (i.e., Subartic Pacific).<ref name=":212">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-EHEP002684.html|title=Wiley: Biological Oceanography, 2nd edition - Charles B. Miller, Patricia A. Wheeler|website=www.wiley.com|access-date=2017-11-11}}</ref> Iron is supplied to the North Pacific by dust storms that occur in Asia and Alaska as well as iron-rich waters [[Advection|advected]] from the continental margin, sometimes by eddies such as [[Haida Eddies]].<ref name=":292">{{Cite journal|last=Boyd|first=P.W.|last2=Mackie|first2=D.S.|last3=Hunter|first3=K.A.|title=Aerosol iron deposition to the surface ocean — Modes of iron supply and biological responses|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0304420309000103|journal=Marine Chemistry|volume=120|issue=1–4|pages=128–143|doi=10.1016/j.marchem.2009.01.008|year=2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hansard | first1 = S. P. | last2 = Landing | first2 = W. M. | last3 = Measures | first3 = C. I. | last4 = Voelker | first4 = B. M. | year = 2009 | title = Dissolved iron (II) in the Pacific Ocean: measurements from the PO2 and P16N CLIVAR/CO 2 repeat hydrography expeditions | url = | journal = Deep Sea Research Part I: Oceanographic Research Papers | volume = 56 | issue = 7| pages = 1117–1129 | doi=10.1016/j.dsr.2009.03.006| bibcode = 2009DSRI...56.1117H }}</ref>
Concentrations of iron however vary throughout the year. Ocean currents are driven by seasonal atmospheric patterns which transport iron from the [[Kuril–Kamchatka Trench|Kuril-Kamchatka]] margin into the western Subarctic Pacific. This introduction of iron provides a subsurface supply of micronutrients, which can be used by primary producers during upwelling of deeper waters to the surface.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lam|first=Phoebe J.|last2=Bishop|first2=James K. B.|date=2008-04-01|title=The continental margin is a key source of iron to the HNLC North Pacific Ocean|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|language=en|volume=35|issue=7|pages=L07608|doi=10.1029/2008gl033294|issn=1944-8007|bibcode=2008GeoRL..35.7608L}}</ref> Seafloor depth may also stimulate phytoplankton blooms in HNLC regions as iron diffuses from the seafloor and alleviates iron limitation in shallow waters.<ref name=":022">{{Cite journal|last=Tyrrell|first=T.|last2=Merico|first2=A.|last3=Waniek|first3=J. J.|last4=Wong|first4=C. S.|last5=Metzl|first5=N.|last6=Whitney|first6=F.|date=2005-12-01|title=Effect of seafloor depth on phytoplankton blooms in high-nitrate, low-chlorophyll (HNLC) regions|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Biogeosciences|language=en|volume=110|issue=G2|pages=G02007|doi=10.1029/2005jg000041|issn=2156-2202|bibcode=2005JGRG..110.2007T}}</ref> Research conducted in the Gulf of Alaska showed that areas with shallow waters, such as the south shelf of Alaska, have more intense phytoplankton blooms than offshore waters.<ref name=":022" /> Volcanic ash from the eruption of the [[Kasatochi Island|Kasatochi]] volcano in August 2008 provided an example of natural iron fertilization in the Northeast Pacific Ocean.<ref name=":28">{{cite journal | last1 = Langmann | first1 = B. | last2 = Zakšek | first2 = K. | last3 = Hort | first3 = M. | last4 = Duggen | first4 = S. | year = 2010 | title = Volcanic ash as fertiliser for the surface ocean | url = | journal = Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics | volume = 10 | issue = 8| pages = 3891–3899 | doi=10.5194/acp-10-3891-2010}}</ref> The region was fertilized by raining volcanic dust containing [[Solubility|soluble]] iron. In the days following, phytoplankton blooms were visible from space.<ref name=":28" />
Limitations in trace metal concentrations in the North Pacific limit diatom blooms throughout the entire year.<ref name=":122">{{Cite journal|last=Pondaven|first=P.|last2=Ruiz-Pino|first2=D.|last3=Druon|first3=J.N.|last4=Fravalo|first4=C.|last5=Tréguer|first5=P.|title=Factors controlling silicon and nitrogen biogeochemical cycles in high nutrient, low chlorophyll systems (the Southern Ocean and the North Pacific): Comparison with a mesotrophic system (the North Atlantic)|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0967063799000333|journal=Deep Sea Research Part I: Oceanographic Research Papers|volume=46|issue=11|pages=1923–1968|doi=10.1016/s0967-0637(99)00033-3|year=1999|bibcode=1999DSRI...46.1923P}}</ref> Even though the North Pacific is an HNLC region, it produces and exports to the ocean interior a relatively high amount of particulate biogenic silica compared to the North Atlantic, which supports significant diatom growth.<ref name=":122" />
=== Equatorial Pacific === The Equatorial Pacific is an oceanic province characterized by nearly year-round upwelling due to the [[Convergence zone|convergence]] of trade winds from the northeast and southeast at the [[Intertropical Convergence Zone]]. The Equatorial Pacific spans nearly half of Earth’s circumference and plays a major role in global marine [[new production|new primary production]].<ref>Chavez, F P., and J R Toggweiler, 1995: '''Physical estimates of global new production: The upwelling contribution''' In ''Dahlem Workshop on Upwelling in the Ocean: Modern Processes and Ancient Records'', Chichester, UK, John Wiley & Sons, 313-320.</ref> New production is a term used in [[biological oceanography]] to describe the way in which nitrogen is recycled within the ocean.<ref name=":212"/> In regions of enhanced new production, [[nitrate]] from the [[aphotic zone]] makes its way into surface waters, replenishing surface nitrate supply. Despite nitrogen availability in Equatorial Pacific waters, primary production and observed surface ocean biomass is considerably lower compared to other major upwelling regions of the ocean.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eppley|first=R. W.|last2=Renger|first2=E. H.|date=1992-01-15|title=Nitrate utilization by plankton in the equatorial Pacific March 1988 along 150°W|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans|language=en|volume=97|issue=C1|pages=663–668|doi=10.1029/91JC01271|issn=2156-2202|bibcode=1992JGR....97..663E}}</ref> Thus the Equatorial Pacific is considered one of the three major HNLC regions.
Like other major HNLC provinces, the Equatorial Pacific is considered nutrient-limited due to lack of trace metals such as iron. The Equatorial Pacific receives approximately 7-10 times more iron from [[Cromwell current|Equatorial Undercurrent]] (EUC) upwelling than from inputs due to settling atmospheric dust.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Winckler|first=Gisela|last2=Anderson|first2=Robert F.|last3=Jaccard|first3=Samuel L.|last4=Marcantonio|first4=Franco|date=2016-05-31|title=Ocean dynamics, not dust, have controlled equatorial Pacific productivity over the past 500,000 years|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/113/22/6119|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=113|issue=22|pages=6119–6124|doi=10.1073/pnas.1600616113|issn=0027-8424|pmid=27185933|pmc=4896667|bibcode=2016PNAS..113.6119W}}</ref> Climate reconstructions of [[glacial periods]] using [[Proxy (climate)#lake and ocean sediments|sediment proxy records]] have revealed that the Equatorial Pacific may have been 2.5 times more productive than the modern equatorial ocean.<ref name=":2" /> During these glacial periods the Equatorial Pacific increased its export of marine new production,<ref name=":2" /> thus providing a sink of atmospheric carbon dioxide. The science of [[paleoceanography]] attempts to understand the interplay of glacial cycles with ocean dynamics. Paleo-oceanographers currently challenge the Aeolian Dust hypothesis which suggests that the transport of atmospheric iron-rich off Central and South America controls the intensity of primary production in the Equatorial Pacific.<ref name=":2" /> One study suggests that because EUC upwelling provides most of the bioavailable iron to the equatorial surface waters, the only method to reverse HNLC conditions is by enhancing upwelling.<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Landry|first=Michael R.|last2=Selph|first2=Karen E.|last3=Taylor|first3=Andrew G.|last4=Décima|first4=Moira|last5=Balch|first5=William M.|last6=Bidigare|first6=Robert R.|date=2011-02-01|title=Phytoplankton growth, grazing and production balances in the HNLC equatorial Pacific|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0967064510002286|journal=Deep Sea Research Part II: Topical Studies in Oceanography|series=Plankton Dynamics and Carbon Cycling in the Equatorial Pacific|volume=58|issue=3|pages=524–535|doi=10.1016/j.dsr2.2010.08.011|bibcode=2011DSRII..58..524L}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> In other words, enhanced regional upwelling, rather than iron-rich atmospheric dust deposition, may explain why this region experiences higher primary productivity during glacial periods.
Compared to the North Pacific and Southern Ocean, Equatorial Pacific waters have relatively low levels of [[biogenic silica]] and thus don't support significant standing stocks of diatoms<ref name=":32"/> Picoplankton are the most abundant marine primary producers in these regions due mainly to their ability to [[Assimilation (biology)|assimilate]] low concentrations of trace metals.<ref name=":32" /> Various phytoplankton communities within the Equatorial Pacific are grazed at the same rate as their growth rate, which further limits primary production.<ref name=":22" />
There is no current consensus regarding which of the two main hypotheses (grazing or micronutrients) controls production in these equatorial waters. It is likely that trace metal limitations select for smaller-celled organisms, which thereby increases the grazing pressure of protists.<ref name=":22" /> While the Equatorial Pacific maintains HNLC characteristics, productivity can be high at times. Productivity leads to an abundance of seabirds such as [[storm petrel]]s near the convergence of subtropical water and the equatorial "cold tongue." The Equatorial Pacific contains the world's largest yellowfin tuna fisheries<ref name=":212" /> and is home to the [[spotted dolphin]].
=== Southern Ocean === [[File:Antarctic_bottom_water_hg.png|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Antarctic_bottom_water_hg.png|thumb|319x319px|A schematic of Antarctic currents. Movement of surface water away from the continent pulls water up from depth.]] The Southern Ocean is the largest HNLC region in the global ocean. The surface waters of the Southern Ocean have been widely identified as being rich in macronutrients despite low phytoplankton stocks.<ref>Chisholm, S. W., & Morel, F. M. (1991). What controls phytoplankton production in nutrient-rich areas of the open sea?</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pollard|first1=Raymond|last2=Tréguer|first2=Paul|last3=Read|first3=Jane|date=2006|title=Quantifying nutrient supply to the Southern Ocean|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|volume=111|issue=C5|pages=C05011|doi=10.1029/2005JC003076|bibcode=2006JGRC..111.5011P}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Morrison|first=Adele K.|last2=Frölicher|first2=Thomas L.|last3=Sarmiento|first3=Jorge L.|date=2015|title=Upwelling in the Southern Ocean|journal=Physics Today|language=en|volume=68|issue=1|pages=27–32|doi=10.1063/PT.3.2654|bibcode=2015PhT....68a..27M}}</ref> Iron deposited in the North Atlantic is incorporated into [[North Atlantic Deep Water]] and is transported to the Southern Ocean via [[thermohaline circulation]].<ref>Sañudo-Wilhelmy, S., and A. R. Flegal (2003), Potential influence of Saharan dust on the chemical composition of the Southern Ocean, Geochem. Geophys. Geosyst., 4, 1063, doi:10.1029/2003GC000507, 7</ref> Eventually mixing with the [[Antarctic Circumpolar Current|Antarctic Circumpolar Water]], upwelling provides iron and macronutrients to the Southern Ocean surface waters. Therefore, iron inputs and primary production in the Southern Ocean are sensitive to iron-rich Saharan dust deposited over the Atlantic. Because of low atmospheric dust inputs directly onto Southern Ocean surface waters,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=de Baar|first=Hein J. W.|last2=Boyd|first2=Philip W.|last3=Coale|first3=Kenneth H.|last4=Landry|first4=Michael R.|last5=Tsuda|first5=Atsushi|last6=Assmy|first6=Philipp|last7=Bakker|first7=Dorothee C. E.|last8=Bozec|first8=Yann|last9=Barber|first9=Richard T.|date=2005-09-01|title=Synthesis of iron fertilization experiments: From the Iron Age in the Age of Enlightenment|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans|language=en|volume=110|issue=C9|pages=C09S16|doi=10.1029/2004jc002601|issn=2156-2202|bibcode=2005JGRC..110.9S16D}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=John H.|last2=Gordon|first2=R. Michael|last3=Fitzwater|first3=Steve E.|date=1990-05-10|title=Iron in Antarctic waters|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=345|issue=6271|pages=156–158|doi=10.1038/345156a0|issn=1476-4687|bibcode=1990Natur.345..156M}}</ref> chlorophyll α concentrations are low. Light availability in the Southern Ocean changes dramatically seasonally, but it does not seem to be a significant constraint on phytoplankton growth.<ref name=":192"/>
Macronutrients present in Southern Ocean surface waters come from upwelled deep water. While micronutrients such as zinc and cobalt may possibly co-limit phytoplankton growth in the Southern Ocean, iron appears to be a critical limiting micronutrient.<ref name=":202"/> Some regions of the Southern Ocean experience both adequate bioavailable iron and macronutrient concentrations yet phytoplankton growth is limited. [[Hydrographic survey|Hydrographic studies]]<ref>Pollard, R., Sanders, R., Lucas, M., Statham, P., 2007. The Crozet natural iron bloom and export experiment (CROZEX). Deep-Sea Res. II: Top. Stud. Oceanogr. 54 (18–20), 1905–1914</ref><ref>Blain, S., Quéguiner, B., Trull, T.W., 2008. The natural iron fertilization experiment KEOPS (KErguelen Ocean and Plateau compared Study): an overview. Deep-Sea Res. II 55, 559–565</ref> and explorations of the Southern Drake Passage region<ref name=":24">{{Cite journal|last=Charette|first=Matt|last2=Sanders|first2=Richard|last3=Zhou|first3=Meng|date=2011|title=Southern Ocean natural iron fertilization|url=http://www.whoi.edu/science/MCG/groundwater/pubs/PDF/Charette%20DSR%20II%20Intro.pdf|journal=Deep-Sea Research II|volume=90|pages=283|via=}}</ref> have observed this phenomenon around the [[Crozet Islands]], [[Kerguelen Islands]], and [[South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Venables|first=Hugh|last2=Moore|first2=C. Mark|date=2010-02-01|title=Phytoplankton and light limitation in the Southern Ocean: Learning from high-nutrient, high-chlorophyll areas|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans|language=en|volume=115|issue=C2|pages=C02015|doi=10.1029/2009JC005361|issn=2156-2202|bibcode=2010JGRC..115.2015V}}</ref><ref name=":24" /> These areas are adjacent to shelf regions of Antarctica and islands of the Southern Ocean. The micronutrients required for algal growth are believed to be supplied from the shelves themselves.<ref name=":24" /> Except in areas close to the Antarctic shelf, micronutrient deficiency severely limits productivity in the Southern Ocean.
Iron availability is not the only regulator of phytoplankton productivity and biomass.<ref name=":252">Liggett, Daniela, Bryan Storey, Yvonne Cook, and Veronika Meduna, eds. ''Exploring the last continent: an introduction to Antarctica''. Springer, 2015.</ref><ref name=":242">{{Cite journal|last=Charette|first=Matt|last2=Sanders|first2=Richard|last3=Zhou|first3=Meng|date=2011|title=Southern Ocean natural iron fertilization|url=http://www.whoi.edu/science/MCG/groundwater/pubs/PDF/Charette%20DSR%20II%20Intro.pdf|journal=Deep-Sea Research II|volume=90|pages=283|via=}}</ref> In the Southern Ocean, prevailing low temperatures are believed to have a negative impact on phytoplankton growth rates.<ref name=":242" /> Phytoplankton growth rate is very intense and short lived in [[Polynya|open areas surrounded by sea ice]] and permanent [[Sea ice|sea-ice zones]]. Grazing by herbivores such as krill, [[copepod]]s and [[salp]]s is believed to suppress phytoplankton standing stock. Unlike the open waters of the Southern Ocean, grazing along continental shelf margins is low, so most phytoplankton that are not consumed sink to the sea floor which provides nutrients to [[Benthic zone|benthic]] organisms.<ref name=":252" />
== Hypotheses == Given the remote location of HNLC areas, scientists have combined modeling and observational data in order to study limits on primary production. Combining these two data sources allows for comparison between the North Pacific, Equatorial Pacific, and Southern Ocean. Two current explanations for global HNLC regions are growth limitations due to iron availability and phytoplankton grazing controls.
=== Iron hypothesis === {{Main article|Iron fertilization|Ocean fertilization}}In 1988, John Martin confirmed the hypothesis that iron limits [[phytoplankton]] blooms and growth rates in the North Pacific. His work was extrapolated to other HNLC regions through evidence which linked low surface iron concentration with low chlorophyll.<ref name=":14"/> In response to [[iron fertilization]] experiments (IronEx, SOIREE, SEEDS, etc.) in HNLC areas, large phytoplankton responses such as decreased surface nutrient concentration and increased [[Primary production|biological activity]] were observed.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=J.H.|last2=Coale|first2=K.H.|last3=Johnson|first3=K.S.|last4=Fitzwater|first4=S.E.|last5=Gordon|first5=R.M.|last6=Tanner|first6=S.J.|last7=Hunter|first7=C.N.|last8=Elrod|first8=V.A.|last9=Nowicki|first9=J.L.|date=September 1994|title=Testing the iron hypothesis in ecosystem of the equatorial Pacific Ocean|url=|journal=Nature|volume=371|issue=6493|pages=123–129|via=|bibcode=1994Natur.371..123M|doi=10.1038/371123a0|hdl=10945/43402}}</ref><ref name=":52">{{Cite journal|last=Fujii|first=Masahiko|last2=Yoshie|first2=Naoki|last3=Yamanaka|first3=Yasuhiro|last4=Chai|first4=Fei|title=Simulated biogeochemical responses to iron enrichments in three high nutrient, low chlorophyll (HNLC) regions|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0079661105000364|journal=Progress in Oceanography|volume=64|issue=2–4|pages=307–324|doi=10.1016/j.pocean.2005.02.017|year=2005|bibcode=2005PrOce..64..307F}}</ref><ref name=":102">{{Cite journal|last=Edwards|first=Andrew M.|last2=Platt|first2=Trevor|last3=Sathyendranath|first3=Shubha|title=The high-nutrient, low-chlorophyll regime of the ocean: limits on biomass and nitrate before and after iron enrichment|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0304380003003028|journal=Ecological Modelling|volume=171|issue=1–2|pages=103–125|doi=10.1016/j.ecolmodel.2003.06.001|year=2004}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Behrenfeld|first=Michael J.|date=10 October 1996|title=Confirmation of iron limitation of phytoplankton photosynthesis in the equatorial Pacific Ocean|url=|journal=Nature|volume=383|issue=6600|pages=508–511|via=|doi=10.1038/383508a0|bibcode=1996Natur.383..508B}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=John H.|last2=Fitzwater|first2=Steve E.|last3=Gordon|first3=R. Michael|date=1990-03-01|title=Iron deficiency limits phytoplankton growth in Antarctic waters|journal=Global Biogeochemical Cycles|language=en|volume=4|issue=1|pages=5–12|doi=10.1029/gb004i001p00005|issn=1944-9224|bibcode=1990GBioC...4....5M}}</ref>
Iron fertilization studies conducted at repeated intervals over the span of a week have produced a larger biological response than a single fertilization event.<ref name=":52"/><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":72">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/tar/wg3/index.php?idp=0|title=IPCC - Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|website=www.ipcc.ch|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> The biological response size tends to depend on a site’s biological, chemical, and physical characteristics. In the Equatorial and North Pacific, silica is thought to constrain additional production after iron fertilization, while light limits additional production in the Southern Ocean.<ref name=":52"/> Native, smaller phytoplankton were initial responders to increased iron, but were quickly outcompeted by larger, coastal phytoplankton such as diatoms.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lam|first=Phoebe J.|last2=Tortell|first2=Philippe D.|last3=Morel|first3=Francois M.M.|date=March 2001|title=Differential effects of iron additions on organic and inorganic carbon production by phytoplankton|url=|journal=American Society of Limnology and Oceanography|volume=46 | issue = 5 |pages=1199–1202|via=|doi=10.4319/lo.2001.46.5.1199|bibcode=2001LimOc..46.1199L}}</ref><ref name=":82">{{Cite journal|last=Trick|first=Charles G.|last2=Bill|first2=Brian D.|last3=Cochlan|first3=William P.|last4=Wells|first4=Mark L.|last5=Trainer|first5=Vera L.|last6=Pickell|first6=Lisa D.|date=2010-03-30|title=Iron enrichment stimulates toxic diatom production in high-nitrate, low-chlorophyll areas|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/107/13/5887|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=107|issue=13|pages=5887–5892|doi=10.1073/pnas.0910579107|issn=0027-8424|pmid=20231473|pmc=2851856|bibcode=2010PNAS..107.5887T}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Tsuda|first=Atsushi|last2=Takeda|last3=Saito|last4=Nishioka|date=July 2007|title=Evidence for the grazing hypothesis: grazing reduces phytoplankton responses of the HNLC ecosystem to iron enrichment in the Western Subarctic Pacific (SEEDS II)|url=|journal=Journal of Oceanography|volume=63|issue=6|pages=983–994|via=|doi=10.1007/s10872-007-0082-x}}</ref> The large bloom response and community shift has led to environmental concerns about fertilizing large sections of HNLC regions. One study suggests that diatoms grow preferentially during fertilization experiments. Some diatoms, such as [[pseudo-nitzschia]], release the neurotoxin [[domoic acid]], poisoning grazing fish.<ref name=":82"/> If diatoms grow preferentially during iron fertilization experiments, sustained fertilizations could enhance domoic acid poisoning in the marine food web near fertilized patches.<ref name=":82"/> [[File:DustDeposition.png|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:DustDeposition.png|left|thumb|390x390px|Global dust deposition from wind. The three HNLC regions (North Pacific, Equatorial Pacific, and Southern Ocean) receive little atmospheric dust, leading to iron deficiencies.]]
==== Aeolian dust ==== {{Main article|Dust}}Iron enters remote HNLC regions through two primary methods: upwelling of nutrient-rich water and atmospheric [[dust]] deposition. Iron needs to be replenished frequently and in bioavailable forms because of its [[Solubility|insolubility]], rapid uptake through biological systems, and binding affinity with [[ligand]]s.<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=Mioni|first=Cécile E.|last2=Handy|first2=Sara M.|last3=Ellwood|first3=Michael J.|last4=Twiss|first4=Michael R.|last5=McKay|first5=R. Michael L.|last6=Boyd|first6=Philip W.|last7=Wilhelm|first7=Steven W.|date=2005-12-01|title=Tracking changes in bioavailable Fe within high-nitrate low-chlorophyll oceanic waters: A first estimate using a heterotrophic bacterial bioreporter|journal=Global Biogeochemical Cycles|language=en|volume=19|issue=4|pages=GB4S25|doi=10.1029/2005gb002476|issn=1944-9224|bibcode=2005GBioC..19.4S25M}}</ref><ref name=":132">{{Cite journal|last=Pitchford|first=Jonathan William|last2=Brindley|first2=John|date=1999|title=Iron limitation, grazing pressure and oceanic high nutrient-low chlorophyll (HNLC) regions|url=|journal=Journal of Plankton Research|volume=21|issue=3|pages=525–547|via=|doi=10.1093/plankt/21.3.525}}</ref> Dust deposition might not result in phytoplankton blooms unless settling dust is in the correct bioavailable form of iron. Additionally, iron must be deposited during productive seasons and coincide with the appropriate RKR-ratios of surface nutrients.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jickells|first=T. D.|last2=An|first2=Z. S.|last3=Andersen|first3=K. K.|last4=Baker|first4=A. R.|last5=Bergametti|first5=G.|last6=Brooks|first6=N.|last7=Cao|first7=J. J.|last8=Boyd|first8=P. W.|last9=Duce|first9=R. A.|date=2005-04-01|title=Global Iron Connections Between Desert Dust, Ocean Biogeochemistry, and Climate|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/308/5718/67|journal=Science|language=en|volume=308|issue=5718|pages=67–71|doi=10.1126/science.1105959|issn=0036-8075|pmid=15802595|bibcode=2005Sci...308...67J|citeseerx=10.1.1.686.1063}}</ref><ref name=":292"/> Aeolian dust has a larger influence on Northern Hemisphere HNLC regions because more land mass contributes to more dust deposition.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Behrenfeld|first=Michael J.|last2=Kolber|first2=Zbigniew S.|date=5 February 1999|title=Widespread iron limitation of phytoplankton in the South Pacific Ocean|url=|journal=Science|volume=283|issue=5403|pages=840–843|via=|doi=10.1126/science.283.5403.840|bibcode=1999Sci...283..840B}}</ref> Due to the Southern Ocean's isolation from land, upwelling related to [[Eddy diffusion|eddy diffusivity]] provides iron to HNLC regions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wagener|first=Thibaut|last2=Guieu|first2=Cécile|last3=Losno|first3=Rémi|last4=Bonnet|first4=Sophie|last5=Mahowald|first5=Natalie|date=2008-06-01|title=Revisiting atmospheric dust export to the Southern Hemisphere ocean: Biogeochemical implications|journal=Global Biogeochemical Cycles|language=en|volume=22|issue=2|pages=GB2006|doi=10.1029/2007gb002984|issn=1944-9224|bibcode=2008GBioC..22.2006W}}</ref>
=== Grazing control hypothesis === Formulated by John Walsh in 1976, the grazing hypothesis states that grazing by [[heterotroph]]s suppresses primary productivity in areas of high nutrient concentrations.<ref name=":9" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Walsh|first=John J.|date=1976-01-01|title=Herbivory as a factor in patterns of nutrient utilization in the sea1|journal=Limnology and Oceanography|language=en|volume=21|issue=1|pages=1–13|doi=10.4319/lo.1976.21.1.0001|issn=1939-5590|bibcode=1976LimOc..21....1W}}</ref> Predation by [[Zooplankton|microzooplankton]] primarily accounts for phytoplankton loss in HNLC regions. Grazing by larger [[zooplankton]] and advective mixing are also responsible for a small proportion of losses to phytoplankton communities.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Frost|first=Bruce W.|date=1991|title=The role of grazing in nutrient-rich areas of the open sea|url=|journal=American Society of Limnology and Oceanography|volume=38|issue=8|pages=1616–1630|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Minas|first=Hans Joachim|last2=Minas|first2=Monique|date=1992|title=Net community production in "High Nutrient-Low Chlorophyll" waters of the tropical and Antarctic Oceans: grazing vs iron hypothesis|url=|journal=Oceanologica Acta|volume=15|issue=2|pages=145–162|via=}}</ref> Constant grazing limits phytoplankton to a low, constant standing stock. Without this [[grazing pressure]], some scientists believe small phytoplankton would produce blooms despite micronutrient depletion because smaller phytoplankton typically have lower iron requirements and can absorb nutrients at a slower rate.<ref name=":16" /><ref name=":15" />
=== Contemporary view === Current scientific consensus agrees that HNLC areas lack high productivity because of a combination of iron and physiological limitations, grazing pressure, and physical forcings.<ref name="pitchford3"/><ref name=":102"/><ref name=":11" /><ref name=":14" /><ref name=":15" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Frost|first=B.W.|date=July 27, 1987|title=Grazing control of phytoplankton stock in the open subarctic Pacific Ocean: a model assessing the role of mesozooplankton, particularly the large calanoid copepods Neocalanus spp.|url=|journal=Marine Ecology Progress Series|volume=39|pages=49–68|via=|doi=10.3354/meps039049|bibcode=1987MEPS...39...49F}}</ref> The extent to which each factor contributes to low production may differ in each HNLC region. Iron limitation allows for smaller, more iron-frugal phytoplankton to grow at rapid rates, while grazing by microzooplankton maintains stable stocks of these smaller phytoplankton.<ref name=":132" /><ref name=":14" /><ref name=":15" /> Once micronutrients become available, grazing may then limit bloom sizes.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":102"/><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":72"/><ref name=":11" /> Additional micronutrient limitations from trace metals like zinc or cobalt may suppress phytoplankton blooms.<ref name=":232"/> Turbulent mixing at higher-latitude HNLC regions (North Pacific and Southern Ocean) may mix phytoplankton below the [[Critical Depth|critical depth]] needed to have community growth.<ref name=":9" />
== Geo-engineering HNLC regions ==
=== Theory === [[File:CO2_pump_hg.svg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CO2_pump_hg.svg|thumb|382x382px|The marine carbon cycle. Carbon dioxide is taken up by phytoplankton for photosynthesis and incorporated into the marine food web. When plankton or predator dies, sedimentation of organic matter reaches the seafloor, where carbon can be buried and sequestered. Stimulating phytoplankton blooms is thought to increase sedimentation of particulate organic carbon after the blooms die off, leading to increased carbon sequestration.]] Since past iron fertilization experiments have resulted in large phytoplankton blooms, some have suggested that large-scale ocean fertilization experiments should be conducted to draw down inorganic anthropogenic carbon dioxide in the form of [[Total organic carbon|particulate organic carbon]]. Fertilization would stimulate biological productivity, leading to a decrease in the amount of inorganic surface carbon dioxide within a fertilized patch. The bloom would then die off and presumably sink to the deep ocean, taking much of the absorbed carbon dixoide to the seafloor and [[Carbon sequestration|sequestering]] it from the short-term [[carbon cycle]] in the deep ocean or ocean sediments.<ref name=":72"/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Behrenfeld|first=Michael J.|last2=Bale|first2=Anthony J.|last3=Kolber|first3=Zbigniew S.|last4=Aiken|first4=James|last5=Falkowski|first5=Paul G.|date=October 1996|title=Confirmation of iron limitation of phytoplankton photosynthesis in the equatorial Pacific Ocean|url=|journal=Nature|volume=383|issue=6600|pages=508–511|via=|doi=10.1038/383508a0|bibcode=1996Natur.383..508B}}</ref><ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Zeebe|first=R. E.|last2=Archer|first2=D.|date=2005-05-01|title=Feasibility of ocean fertilization and its impact on future atmospheric CO2 levels|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|language=en|volume=32|issue=9|pages=L09703|doi=10.1029/2005gl022449|issn=1944-8007|bibcode=2005GeoRL..32.9703Z}}</ref><ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/contents.html|title=Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007|website=www.ipcc.ch|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://voices.nationalgeographic.org/2012/10/18/iron-fertilization-savior-to-climate-change-or-ocean-dumping/|title=Iron Fertilization: Savoir to Climate Change or Ocean Dumping?|last=Waller|first=Rhian|date=18 October 2012|work=National Geographic|access-date=20 October 2017}}</ref>
=== Efficiency and efficacy === To effectively remove anthropogenic carbon from the atmosphere, iron fertilization would need to result in significant removal of particulate carbon from the surface ocean and transport it to the deep ocean.<ref name=":52"/><ref name=":102"/><ref name=":18" /><ref name=":17" /> Various studies estimated that less than 7-10% of carbon taken up during a bloom would be sequestered,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Boyd|first=Philip W.|last2=Law|first2=Cliff S.|last3=Wong|first3=C.S.|last4=Nojiri|first4=Yukihiro|last5=Tsuda|first5=Atsushi|last6=Levasseur|first6=Maurice|last7=Takeda|first7=Shigenobu|last8=Rivkin|first8=Richard|last9=Harrison|first9=Paul J.|date=2004-03-17|title=The decline and fate of an iron-induced subarctic phytoplankton bloom|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=428|issue=6982|pages=549–553|doi=10.1038/nature02437|pmid=15058302|issn=1476-4687|bibcode=2004Natur.428..549B}}</ref> and only a 15-25 [[Parts-per notation|ppm]] decrease in atmospheric carbon dioxide would result with sustained global iron fertilization.<ref name=":272"/><ref name=":18" /> The amount of carbon dioxide removed may be offset by the fuel cost of acquiring, transporting, and releasing significant amounts of iron into remote HNLC regions.<ref name=":17" />
Many environmental concerns exist for large-scale iron fertilization. While blooms can be studied and traced, scientists still do not know if the extra production gets incorporated into the food chain or falls to the deep ocean after a bloom dies off.<ref name=":52" /><ref name=":102" /> Even if carbon is exported to depth, raining organic matter can be respired, potentially creating mid-column [[Anoxic waters|anoxic]] zones or causing [[Ocean acidification|acidification]] of deep ocean water.<ref name=":17" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cao|first=Long|last2=Caldeira|first2=Ken|date=2010-03-01|title=Can ocean iron fertilization mitigate ocean acidification?|journal=Climatic Change|language=en|volume=99|issue=1–2|pages=303–311|doi=10.1007/s10584-010-9799-4|issn=0165-0009}}</ref> Pronounced community shifts to diatoms have been observed during fertilization, and it’s still unclear if the change in species composition has any long-term environmental effects.<ref name=":82"/><ref name=":17" />
== See also == *[[Antarctic krill]] *[[Iron fertilization]] *[[Iron Hypothesis]] *[[John Martin (oceanographer)]] *[[Marine snow]] *[[Primary production]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{plankton}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hnlc}} [[Category:Aquatic ecology]] [[Category:Planktology]] [[Category:Oceanography]]

revision.comment: Reduce whitespace
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2013}}
In [[physics]], a '''high contrast grating''' is a single layer near-[[wavelength]] [[grating]] physical structure where the grating material has a large contrast in [[index of refraction]] with its surroundings. The term near-wavelength refers to the grating [[Period (frequency)|period]], which has a value between one optical wavelength in the grating material and that in its surrounding materials.
The high contrast gratings have many distinct attributes that are not found in conventional gratings. These features include broadband ultra-high [[reflectivity]], broadband ultra-high [[transmission (wave propagation)|transmission]], and very high [[quality factor]] [[resonance]], for optical beam surface-normal or in oblique incidence to the grating surface. The high reflectivity grating can be ultrathin, only <0.15 optical wavelength. The reflection and transmission phase of the optical beam through the high contrast grating can be engineered to cover a full 2π range while maintaining a high reflection or transmission coefficient.
[[File:HighContrastGrating.png|thumb|Schematics of high contrast grating. Λ, grating period; k<sub>o</sub>, incident light wave vector; n<sub>bar</sub>, refractive index of grating bar; n<sub>o</sub>, refractive index of the surrounding medium of the grating bar.]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Schematics of High Contrast Grating.png|thumb|right|Schematics of high contrast grating. Λ, grating period; k<sub>o</sub>, incident light wave vector; n<sub>bar</sub>, refractive index of grating bar; n<sub>o</sub>, refractive index of the surrounding medium of the grating bar.]] --> == History ==
The concept of high contrast grating took off with a report on a broadband high reflectivity reflector for surface-normal incident light (the ratio between the wavelength bandwidth with a reflectivity larger than 0.99 and the central wavelength is greater than 30%) in 2004 by [[Constance J. Chang-Hasnain]] et al.,<ref>C. F. R. Mateus, M. C. Y. Huang, Y. Deng, A. R. Neureuther, and C. J. Chang-Hasnain, “Ultra-broadband mirror using low index cladded subwavelength grating”, IEEE Photon. Technol. Lett. 16, 518-520 (2004).</ref><ref>C. J. Chang-Hasnain, C. F. R. Mateus, and M. C. Y. Huang, “Ultra broadband mirror using subwavelength grating,” U.S. Patent 7,304,781 (Dec. 4, 2007).</ref> which was demonstrated experimentally in the same year.<ref>C. F. R. Mateus, M. C. Y. Huang, L. Chen, and C. J. Chang-Hasnain and Y. Suzuki, “Broadband mirror (1.12-1.62 um) using single-layer sub-wavelength grating”, IEEE Photon. Technol. Lett. 16, 1676-1678 (2004).</ref> The key idea is to have the high-refractive-index material all surrounded by low-refractive-index material. They are subsequently applied as a highly reflective mirror in [[vertical-cavity surface-emitting laser]]s,<ref name=NP2007>M. C. Y. Huang, Y. Zhou, and C. J. Chang-Hasnain, “A surface-emitting laser incorporating a high index-contrast subwavelength grating,” Nat.Photonics 1(2), 119–122 (2007).</ref> as well as monolithic, continuously wavelength tunable vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers.<ref name=NP2008>M. C. Y. Huang, Y. Zhou, and C. J. Chang-Hasnain, “A nanoelectromechanical tunable laser,” Nat. Photonics 2, 180–184 (2008).</ref> The properties of high contrast grating are rapidly explored since then. The following lists some relevant examples:
In 2008, a single layer of high contrast grating was demonstrated as a high quality factor cavity.<ref name=OE2008>Y. Zhou, M. Moewe, J. Kern, M. C. Y. Huang, and C. J. Chang-Hasnain,“Surface-normal emission of a high-Q resonator using a subwavelength high-contrast grating,” Opt. Express 16(22), 17282–17287 (2008).</ref> In 2009, hollow-core [[waveguides]] using high contrast grating were proposed,<ref name=OE2009>Y. Zhou, V. Karagodsky, B. Pesala, F. G. Sedgwick, and C. J. ChangHasnain, “A novel ultra-low loss hollow-core waveguide using subwavelength high-contrast gratings,” Opt. Express 17(3), 1508–1517 (2009).</ref> followed by experimentally demonstration in 2012.<ref name=NANOP2012>W. Yang, J. Ferrara, K. Grutter, A. Yeh, C. Chase, Y. Yue, A. E. Willner, M. C. Wu, and C. J. Chang-Hasnain, ”Low loss hollow-core waveguide on a silicon substrate,” Nanophotonics 1(1), 23–29 (2012).</ref> This experiment is the first demonstration to show a high contrast grating reflecting optical beam propagating in the direction parallel to the gratings, which is a major distinction from [[photonic crystal]] or [[distributed Bragg reflector]].
In 2010, planar, single-layer [[Lens (optics)|lens]]es and focusing reflectors with high focusing power using a high contrast grating with spatially varying grating dimensions were proposed and demonstrated.<ref name=OE2010_1>F. Lu, F. G. Sedgwick, V. Karagodsky, C. Chase, and C. J. Chang-Hasnain,“Planar high-numerical-aperture low-loss focusing reflectors and lenses using subwavelength high contrast gratings,” Opt. Express 18, 12606–12614 (2010).</ref><ref name=NP2010>D. Fattal, J. Li, Z. Peng, M. Fiorentino, and R. G. Beausolei, “Flat dielectric grating reflectors with focusing abilities,” Nat. Photonics 4(7), 466–470 (2010).</ref> Some literatures quote the high contrast gratings as photonic crystal slabs or photonic crystal membranes.<ref>X. Letartre, J. Mouette, J. L. Leclercq, P. R. Romeo, C. Seassal, and P. Viktorovitch, “Switching devices with spatial and spectral resolution combining photonic crystal and MOEMS structures,” IEEE J. Lightwave Technol. 21, 1691-1699 (2003).</ref><ref name=PTL2012>C. Sciancalepore, B.B. Bakir, X. Letartre, J. Harduin, N. Olivier, C. Seassal, J. Fedeli, P. Viktorovitch, “CMOS-compatible ultra-compact 1.55- μ m emitting VCSELs using double photonic crystal mirrors”, IEEE Photon. Technol. Lett. 24, 455-457 (2012).</ref>
== Principle of operation ==
Fully rigorous electromagnetic solutions exist for gratings, which tends to involve heavy mathematical formulism. A simple analytical formulism to explain the various properties of high contrast grating has been developed.<ref>P. Lalanne, J.P. Hugonin and P. Chavel, “Optical properties of deep lamellar gratings: a coupled Bloch-mode insight”, IEEE J. of Lightwave Technol. 24, 2442 (2006).</ref><ref>V. Karagodsky, F.G. Sedgwick and C.J. Chang-Hasnain, “Theoretical analysis of subwavelength high contrast Grating Reflectors”, Optics Express 18, 16973 (2010).</ref><ref>C. J. Chang-Hasnain and W. Yang, "High-contrast gratings for integrated optoelectronics," Adv. Opt. Photon. 4, 379-440 (2012).</ref> A computational program based on this analytical solution has also been developed to solve the electromagnetic properties of high contrast grating, named High Contrast Grating Solver.<ref>[http://light.eecs.berkeley.edu/cch/hcgsolver.html "High Contrast Grating Solver"]</ref> The following provides a brief overview of the operation principle of high contrast grating.
The grating bars can be considered as merely a periodic array of waveguides with wave being guided along the grating thickness direction. Upon plane wave incidence, depending on wavelength and grating dimensions, only a few waveguide-array modes are excited. Due to a large index contrast and near-wavelength dimensions, there exists a wide wavelength range where only two waveguide-array modes have real propagation constants in the z direction and, hence, carry energy. The two waveguide-array modes then depart from the grating input plane and propagate downward to the grating exiting plane, and then reflect back up. After propagating through the grating thickness, each propagating mode accumulates a different phase. At the exiting plane, owing to a strong mismatch with the exiting plane wave, the waveguide modes not only reflect back to themselves but also couple into each other. As the modes propagate and return to the input plane, similar mode coupling occurs. Following the modes through one round trip, the reflectivity solution can be attained. The two modes interfere at the input and exiting plane of the high contrast grating, leading to various distinct properties.
== Applications ==
High contrast gratings have been employed in many optoelectronic devices. It has been incorporated as the mirrors for vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers.<ref name=NP2007 /><ref name=NP2008 /><ref name=PTL2012 /><ref name=OE2010_2>V. Karagodsky, B. Pesala, C. Chase, W. Hofmann, F. Koyama and C.J. Chang-Hasnain, “Monolithically integrated multi-wavelength VCSEL arrays using high-contrast gratings”, Optics Express 18, 694 (2010).</ref> The light-weight of high contrast grating enables fast microelectromechanical structure actuation for wavelength tuning.<ref name=NP2008 /> The reflection phase of the high contrast grating is engineered to control the emission wavelength of vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers.<ref name=OE2010_2 /> By locally changing each grating dimension while keeping its thickness the same, planar, single-layer lenses and focusing reflectors with high focusing power have been obtained.<ref name=OE2010_1 /><ref name=NP2010 /> Besides its high reflectivity, the high contrast grating has been designed as a high quality factor resonator.<ref name=OE2008 /><ref>T.-T. Wu, S.-H. Wu, T.-C. Lu, and S.-C. Wang, “GaN-based high contrast grating surface-emitting lasers,” Appl. Phys. Lett. 102, 081111 (2013).</ref> Low-loss hollow-core waveguide are made with high contrast gratings with high reflectivity at oblique incident angle.<ref name=OE2009 /><ref name=NANOP2012 /> Applications such as slow light <ref>T. Sun, W. Yang, V. Karagodsky, W. Zhou, and C. Chang-Hasnain, “Low-loss slow light inside high contrast grating waveguide,” Proc. SPIE 8270, 82700A (2012).</ref> and optical switch <ref>W. Yang and C. J. Chang-Hasnain, “Ultra-compact optical switch using high contrast grating hollow-core waveguide,” Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics, OSA Technical Digest (CD) (Optical Society of America, 2013).</ref> can be built on the hollow-core waveguide by using the special phase response and resonance property of high contrast grating. High contrast grating can effectively manipulate the light propagation – directing light from surface-normal to in-plane index-guided waveguide and vice versa.<ref>L. Zhu, V. Karagodsky, and C. Chang-Hasnain, “Novel high efficiency vertical to in-plane optical coupler,” Proc. SPIE 8270, 82700L (2012).</ref>
== References ==
{{Reflist}}
[[Category:Waves]]

revision.comment: v2.0b - [[WP:WCW]] project (Unicode control characters)
revision.text:
{{short description|A branch of meteorology and hydrology that studies the transfer of water and energy between the land surface and the lower atmosphere}} '''Hydrometeorology''' is a branch of [[meteorology]] and [[hydrology]] that studies the transfer of [[water]] and [[energy]] between the land surface and the lower [[atmosphere]]. [[Hydrology|Hydrologists]] often utilize [[meteorologists]] and products produced by meteorologists<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Peck|first=Eugene L.|date=1978|title=Hydrometeorology|url=https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0477-59.5.609|journal=Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society|volume=59(5)|pages=609-612|via=}}</ref> As an example, a meteorologist would forecast 2-3 inches of rain is a specific area, and a hydrologist would then forecast what the specific impact of that rain would be on the terrain.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Hydrometeorology: Forecasting and Applications|last=Sene|first=Kevin|publisher=Springer International Publishing Switzerland|year=2015|isbn=978-3-319-23546-2|location=|pages=1}}</ref> [[UNESCO]] has several programmes and activities in place that deal with the study of [[natural hazards]] of hydrometeorological origin and the mitigation of their effects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/special-themes/disaster-risk-reduction/natural-hazards/hydro-meteorological-hazards/|title=Hydro-meteorological hazards | United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|date=|publisher=Unesco.org|accessdate=2016-08-05}}</ref> Among these hazards are the results of natural processes or [[Atmosphere|atmospheric]], [[Hydrology|hydrological]], or [[oceanographic]] phenomena such as [[flood]]s, [[tropical cyclone]]s, [[drought]] and [[desertification]]. Many countries have established an operational hydrometeorological capability to assist with [[weather forecasting|forecasting]], warning, and informing the public of these developing hazards.
== Hydrometeorological Forecasting == One of the more significant aspects of hydrometeorology has to do with the prediction and attempt to mitigate the effects of high precipitation events.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dale|first=Murray|last2=Davies|first2=Paul|last3=Harrison|first3=Tim|date=2012|title=Review of recent advances in UK operational hydrometeorology|url=https://doi.org/10.1680/wama.2012.165.2.55|journal=Proceedings of the Institution of Civil Engineers : Water management|volume=165|pages=55-64|doi=|via=}}</ref> Beginning with the prediction, there are three primary ways to to model when coming to forecasting. These are now-casting, numerical weather prediction, and statistical techniques.<ref name=":0" /> [[Nowcasting (meteorology)|Now-casting]] is good for predicting events for a few hours out, utilizing observations and live radar data to combine with the numerical weather prediction models.<ref name=":0" /> [[Numerical weather prediction]], which is the primary technique used to forecast weather, uses models to take account of the atmosphere, ocean models, and accounts for many other variables when it produces forecasts.<ref name=":0" /> These forecasts are generally used for predictions days or weeks out.<ref name=":0" /> Finally, statistical techniques utilize regressions and other statistical methods to create long-term projections that go out weeks and months at a time.<ref name=":0" /> These models allow scientists to view how a multitude of different variables interact with one another, and they illustrate one picture in how earth's climate interacts with itself.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Betts|first=Alan|date=2004|title=Understanding Hydrometeorology Using Global Models|url=https://doi.org/10.1175/BAMS-85-11-1673|journal=American Meteorological Society|volume=|pages=1673-1688|via=}}</ref>
== Risk Assessment == A major component of hydrometeorology is mitigating the risk associated with flooding and other hydrological threats. First, there has to be knowledge of the possible hydrological threats that are expected within a specific region.<ref name=":0" /> After analyzing the possible threats, warning systems are put in place to quickly alert people and communicate to them the identity and magnitude of the threat.<ref name=":0" /> Many nations have their own specific regional hydrometeorological centers that communicate threats to the public. Finally, there has to be proper response protocols in place to protect the public during a dangerous event.<ref name=":0" />
==Operational Hydrometeorology in Practice== [[File:1932 Velasco hurricane rainfall totals.png|thumb|Rainfall forecasts for the 1932 Velasco Hurricane produced by the US [[Weather Prediction Center|Hydrometeorlogical Prediction Center]] (Now Weather Prediction Center)]] Countries with a current operational hydrometeorology service include, among others: * [[Bureau of Meteorology|Australia]] * [[Environment Canada|Canada]] * [[Flood Forecasting Centre|England and Wales (Flood Forecasting Centre)]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ffc-environment-agency.metoffice.gov.uk |title=Flood Forecasting Centre |publisher=Ffc-environment-agency.metoffice.gov.uk|date=2011-09-22|accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref> * France<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vigicrues.gouv.fr |title=Information nationale |publisher=Vigicrues|accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref> * India<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imd.gov.in/section/hydro/static/welcome.htm |title=Hydro-Meteorology |publisher=Imd.gov.in |accessdate=2014-05-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140630013814/http://www.imd.gov.in/section/hydro/static/welcome.htm |archivedate=2014-06-30 |df= }}</ref> * Scotland<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sepa.org.uk/flooding/flood_forecasting_service.aspx |title=Flood Forecasting Service |publisher=Sepa.org.uk|accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref> * Serbia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hidmet.gov.rs/index_eng.php |title=Republic Hydrometeorological service of Serbia Kneza Višeslava 66 Beograd|publisher=Hidmet.gov.rs |date=2014-05-18|accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref> * [[Hydrometeorological Centre of Russia|Russia]] * [[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|The United States of America]] * Brazil<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cemaden.gov.br/ |title=Centro Nacional de Monitoramento e Alerta de Desastres Naturais (Cemaden) |publisher=labhidro-IGEO-UFRJ|accessdate=2017-06-29}}</ref>
==References==
<references />
==External links== * [http://www.wmo.int/pages/members/membership/nhs_en.html World Meteorological Organization List of national hydrological and hydrometeorological services]
[[Category:Hydrology]] [[Category:Climatology]] [[Category:Branches of meteorology]] [[Category:Oceanography]]
{{Climate-stub}}

revision.comment: The original sentence was linguistically ambiguous and could easily be misinterpreted as: dust that pervades the space between our planets and exoplanetsets
revision.text:
The '''interplanetary dust cloud''', or '''zodiacal cloud''', consists of [[cosmic dust]] (small particles floating in [[outer space]]) that pervades the space between [[planet]]s within [[planetary system]]s such as the [[Solar System]]. This system of particles has been studied for many years in order to understand its nature, origin, and relationship to larger bodies.
In our [[Solar System]], the interplanetary dust particles have a role in [[light scattering by particles|scattering]] [[sunlight]] and in emitting [[thermal radiation]], which is the most prominent feature of the [[night sky]]'s radiation with wavelengths ranging 5–50 [[micrometer|μm]].<ref>Levasseur-Regourd, A.C., 1996</ref> The [[particle size]]s of grains characterizing the [[infrared]] emission near [[Earth's orbit]] typically range 10–100 μm.<ref>Backman, D., 1997</ref>
The total mass of the interplanetary dust cloud is approximately the mass of an [[asteroid]] of radius 15 km (with density of about 2.5 g/cm<sup>3</sup>).<ref>{{cite journal |last=Pavlov |first=Alexander A. |date= |title=Irradiated interplanetary dust particles as a possible solution for the deuterium/hydrogen paradox of Earth's oceans |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/1999JE001120/full#references |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Planets |volume=104 |pages=30725-28}}</ref> Straddling the [[zodiac]] along the [[ecliptic]], this dust cloud is visible as the [[zodiacal light]] in a moonless and naturally dark sky and is best seen toward the Sun's direction during astronomical [[twilight]].
== Origin == The sources of interplanetary dust particles (IDPs) include at least: asteroid collisions, [[comet]]ary activity and collisions in the inner Solar System, [[Kuiper belt]] collisions, and [[interstellar medium]] grains (Backman, D., 1997). Indeed, one of the longest-standing controversies debated in the interplanetary dust community revolves around the relative contributions to the interplanetary dust cloud from asteroid collisions and cometary activity.
== Life cycle of a particle ==
The main physical processes "affecting" (destruction or expulsion mechanisms) interplanetary dust particles are: expulsion by [[radiation pressure]], inward [[Poynting-Robertson drag|Poynting-Robertson (PR) radiation drag]], [[solar wind]] pressure (with significant electromagnetic effects), [[Sublimation (chemistry)|sublimation]], mutual collisions, and the dynamical effects of planets (Backman, D., 1997).
The lifetimes of these dust particles are very short compared to the lifetime of the Solar System. If one finds grains around a star that is older than about 10,000,000 years, then the grains must have been from recently released fragments of larger objects, i.e. they cannot be leftover grains from the [[protoplanetary disk]] (Backman, private communication).{{cn|reason=We can't use private communications. Technically I ought to remove this claim. But I don't want to, because it's very interesting and seems likely to be supported — just someone needs to find an RS.|date=March 2018}} Therefore, the grains would be "later-generation" dust. The zodiacal dust in the Solar System is 99.9% later-generation dust and 0.1% intruding [[interstellar medium]] dust. All primordial grains from the Solar System's formation were removed long ago.
Particles which are affected primarily by radiation pressure are known as "beta meteoroids". They are generally less than 1.4 × 10<sup>−12</sup> g and are pushed outward from the Sun into interstellar space.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gps.caltech.edu/genesis/DocumentN.html#BeMe |accessdate=August 4, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070826132615/http://www.gps.caltech.edu/genesis/DocumentN.html |archivedate=August 26, 2007 }}</ref>
== Cloud structures ==
The interplanetary dust cloud has a complex structure (Reach, W., 1997). Apart from a background density, this includes: * At least 8 [[dust trail]]s—their source is thought to be [[short-period comet]]s. * A number of dust bands, the sources of which are thought to be [[asteroid families]] in the [[main asteroid belt]]. The three strongest bands arise from the [[Themis family]], the [[Koronis family]], and the [[Eos family]]. Other source families include the [[Maria family|Maria]], [[Eunomia family|Eunomia]], and possibly the [[Vesta family|Vesta]] and/or [[Hygiea family|Hygiea]] families (Reach et al. 1996). * At least 2 resonant dust rings are known (for example, the Earth-resonant dust ring, although every planet in the Solar System is thought to have a resonant ring with a "wake") (Jackson and Zook, 1988, 1992) (Dermott, S.F. et al., 1994, 1997)
== Dust collection on Earth==
In 1951, [[Fred Whipple]] predicted that micrometeorites smaller than 100 micrometers in diameter might be decelerated on impact with the Earth's upper atmosphere without melting.<ref name="Whipple-1950" /> The modern era of laboratory study of these particles began with the stratospheric collection flights of D. E. Brownlee and collaborators in the 1970s using balloons and then [[Lockheed U-2|U-2]] aircraft.<ref name="Brownlee-1977" />
Although some of the particles found were similar to the material in present-day meteorite collections, the [[nanoporous]] nature and unequilibrated cosmic-average composition of other particles suggested that they began as fine-grained aggregates of nonvolatile building blocks and cometary ice.<ref>P. Fraundorf, D. E. Brownlee, and R. M. Walker (1982) Laboratory studies of interplanetary dust, in ''Comets'' (ed. L. Wilkening, U. Arizona Press, Tucson) pp. 383-409.</ref><ref name="Walker-1986" /> The interplanetary nature of these particles was later verified by [[noble gas]]<ref name="Hudson-1981" /> and [[solar flare]] track<ref name="Bradley-1984" /> observations.
In that context a program for atmospheric collection and curation of these particles was developed at [[Johnson Space Center]] in Texas.<ref name="Cosmic-Dust-Sample-Collection" /> This stratospheric micrometeorite collection, along with [[presolar grains]] from meteorites, are unique sources of [[extraterrestrial material]] (not to mention being small astronomical objects in their own right) available for study in laboratories today.

Jayaraman, S., Xu, Y.L., Gustafson, A.A.S., Liou, J.C., | title=A circumsolar ring of asteroid dust in resonant lock with the Earth | journal=Nature| date=June 30, 1994 | volume=369 | pages=719–23 | doi = 10.1038/369719a0 |bibcode = 1994Natur.369..719D | issue=6483 }} * {{cite conference | author=Dermott, S.F. | title=Signatures of Planets in Zodiacal Light | booktitle=Extrasolar Zodiacal Emission - NASA Study Panel Report | date=1997 | pages=}} * {{cite conference | author=Levasseur-Regourd, A.C. | title=Optical and Thermal Properties of Zodiacal Dust | booktitle=Physics, Chemistry and Dynamics of Interplanetary Dust, ASP Conference series, Vol 104 | date=1996 | pages=301-}} * {{cite conference | author=Reach, W. | title=General Structure of the Zodiacal Dust Cloud | booktitle=Extrasolar Zodiacal Emission - NASA Study Panel Report | date=1997 | pages=}} * {{cite journal |author1=Reach, W.T. |author2=Franz, B.A. |author3=Weiland, J.L. | title=The Three-Dimensional Structure of the Zodiacal Dust Bands | journal=Icarus| date=1997 | volume=127 | pages=461–484 | doi=10.1006/icar.1997.5704 | bibcode=1997Icar..127..461R | issue=2}}
