{{Infobox rockunit | name = Tobífera Formation | image = | caption = | type = [[Geological formation]] | period = Late Jurassic | age = [[Late Jurassic]] | prilithology = [[Felsic|Silicic]] [[pyroclastic rock]]s (including [[tuff]]) | otherlithology = [[Black shale]], [[intrusion (geology)|silicic intrusions]], [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]], [[sandstone]] | namedfor = | namedby = | region = [[Magallanes y la Antártica Chilena Region]] | country = {{CHL}} | coordinates = | unitof = | subunits = Basal Clastic Complex | underlies = [[Zapata Formation|Zapata]], [[Springhill Formation|Springhill]] & [[Chon Aike Formation]]s | overlies = [[Tierra del Fuego Igneous and Metamorphic Complex]]
[[Cordillera Darwin Metamorphic Complex]] | thickness = | extent = Rocas Verdes Basin
 [[Magallanes Basin|Magallanes]] & [[Malvinas Basin]]s | area = | map = | map_caption = }} '''Tobífera Formation''' ({{lang-es|Formación Tobífera}}) is a [[Volcano-sedimentary sequence|volcano-sedimentary]] [[sedimentary formation|formation]] of [[Late Jurassic]] age. The formation is located in [[Magallanes Region]] in southern [[Patagonia]] and [[Tierra del Fuego]]. The bulk of the formation originates from [[felsic|silicic]] [[pyroclast|pyroclastic material]] during a period of [[bimodal volcanism]] in [[Magallanes Basin|Rocas Verdes Basin]], a [[rift]] [[sedimentary basin|basin]].Fildani, Andrea, Romans, B.W., Fosdick, J.C., Crane, W.H., and Hubbard, S.M. (2008). [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Stephen_Hubbard2/publication/228748203_Orogenesis_of_the_Patagonian_Andes_as_reflected_by_basin_evolution_in_southernmost_South_America/links/09e4151361a1584663000000.pdf Orogenesis of the Patagonian Andes as reflected by basin evolution in southernmost South America], in Spencer, J.E., and Titley, S.R., eds., Ores and orogenesis: Circum-Pacific tectonics, geologic evolution, and ore deposits: ''Arizona Geological Society Digest'' '''22''': 259-268. The Tobífera Formation is grouped together with other formations of similar age in Patagonia in the [[Chon Aike Province]] an extraordinarily large province of silicic volcanism.{{cite journal | last1 = Pankhurst | first1 = R.J. | authorlink = Robert John Pankhurst | last2 = Riley | first2 = T.R. | last3 = Fanning | first3 = C.M. | last4 = Kelley | first4 = S.P. | year = 2000 | title = Episodic silicic volcanism in Patagonia and the Antarctic Peninsula: chronology of magmatism associated with the break-up of Gondwana | url = | journal = [[Journal of Petrology]] | volume = 41 | issue = 5| pages = 605–625 | doi=10.1093/petrology/41.5.605}} Except for some western and southern [[outcrop|exposures]] most of the formation is buried and known only from [[borehole]]s in [[Magallanes Basin]]. The formation is equivalent to [[El Quemado Formation|El Quemado]] and [[Ibañez Formation]]s. Tobífera Formation has an up to {{convert|80|m|ft}} thick Basal Clastic Complex, a sub-unit made up of [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]] and [[sandstone]]. Tobífera Formation [[unconformity|unconformably]] overlies [[metamorphic rock|metamorphic]] and [[igneous rock|igneous]] [[basement (geology)|basement]] [[Complex (geology)|complexes]] of Cambrian age.{{cite journal |last=Hervé |first=F. |last2=Fanning |first2=C.M. |last3=Pankhurst |first3=R.J. |last4=Mpodozis |first4=C. |last5=Klepeis |first5=K. |last6=Calderón |first6=M. |last7=Thomson |first7=S.N.|author-link1=Francisco Hervé |author-link3=Robert John Pankhurst|author-link4=Constantino Mpodozis |date=2010 |title=Detrital zircon SHRIMP U–Pb age study of the Cordillera Darwin Metamorphic Complex of Tierra del Fuego: sedimentary sources and implications for the evolution of the Pacific margin of Gondwana |url= |journal=Journal of the Geological Society, London |publisher= |volume=167 |issue= |pages=555–568 |doi= 10.1144/0016-76492009-124}} == Deformation and metamorphism == Much of the formation is [[fold (geology)|folded]] and [[fault (geology)|fault]]ed as consequence of the [[Andean orogeny]]. At [[Última Esperanza Province]] the formation [[metamorphism|metamorphosed]] first under [[greenschist facies]] and then under [[prehnite-pumpellyite facies]] conditions.{{cite journal |last=Galaz |first=Gonzalo |last2=Hervé |first2=Francisco |last3=Calderón|first3=Mauricio|author-link2=Francisco Hervé |date=2005 |title=Metamorfismo y deformación de la Formación Tobífera en la cordillera Riesco, región de Magallanes, Chile: evidencias para su evolución tectónica |url=http://www.scielo.org.ar/scielo.php?script=sci_abstract&pid=S0004-48222005000400013 |journal=[[Revista de la Asociación Geológica Argentina]] |publisher= |volume=60 |issue=4 |pages=762–774 |doi= |access-date=26 August 2016 |language=Spanish}} Some [[rhyolite]]s of Tobífera Formation were incorporated into [[Cordillera Darwin Metamorphic Complex]]. The incorporation of part of Tobífera Formation in the metamorphic complex was accompanied by deformation and metamorphism and occurred in the context of the Andean orogeny in the [[Cretaceous]]. == References == {{portal|Geology|Jurassic|Prehistory of South America}} {{reflist}} {{Geology of Chile}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tobifera Formation}} [[Category:Geologic formations of Chile]] [[Category:Geologic formations of Argentina]] [[Category:Jurassic Argentina]] [[Category:Jurassic Chile]] [[Category:Jurassic volcanism]] [[Category:Tuff formations]] [[Category:Geology of Magallanes y la Antártica Chilena Region]] [[Category:Geology of Aysén Region]] [[Category:Natural history of Tierra del Fuego]]

revision.text:
{{news release|1=article|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox person |name=Tom Dinwoodie |birth_name=Thomas Linn Dinwoodie |image= |image_size=220 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1954|11|15}} |birth_place=[[St. Paul, Minnesota]], [[United States]] |alma_mater=[[Cornell University]]
[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)]]
[[University of California, Berkeley]] |occupation=Solar Energy and Cleantech entrepreneur |known_for=Executive Producer, [http://timetochoose.com Time to Choose], a climate solutions documentary
SunPower Corporation Systems, CTO
PowerLight Corporation, Founder, President, and CEO }} '''Thomas Linn Dinwoodie''' (born November 15, 1954) is a cleantech entrepreneur, inventor, and founder of [[SunPower|SunPower Corporation Systems]] (formerly PowerLight Corporation). He holds a long-standing interest in accelerating the transition to clean energy and other climate-sustaining practices. Dinwoodie is also an architect. == Early business initiatives == From 1978 to 1983, Dinwoodie was a research assistant at the MIT Energy Laboratory, where he authored numerous papers on the economics and policy of distributed solar and wind generation, as well as flywheel energy storage. In 1981, Dinwoodie was awarded a contract from the U.S. DOE for development of an ultra-low-cost, polymer solar thermal collector. He was Founder, President and CEO of TDEnergy, a wind power developer in the U.S. Northeast, from 1982 to 1988. TDEnergy constructed one of the earliest New England wind power facilities in Canaan, NH. Dinwoodie then founded PowerLight Corporation in 1994, and served as its CEO and Chairman of the Board from 1995 to 2007. PowerLight was a global manufacturer, supplier, and systems integrator of solar products and services for the residential, commercial, and utility sectors.{{cite web|last=Turner |first=Rob |url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fsb/fsb_archive/2003/06/01/346434/ |title=Tom Dinwoodie, CEO, Powerlight, Berkeley Thanks to one innovative, sun-obsessed engineer, the price of solar power is becoming much more competitive. - June 1, 2003 |website=Money.cnn.com |date=2003-06-01 |accessdate=2017-02-24}} In 2004, PowerLight was inducted into the INC 500 Hall of Fame.{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/20060901/inc500-hall-of-fame.html |title=Inc. 500 Hall of Fame, Growing Your Business Article |website=Inc.com |date=2009-10-28 |accessdate=2017-02-24}} PowerLight merged with SunPower Corporation in 2007,{{cite web|url=http://investors.sunpowercorp.com/common/mobile/iphone/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=225327&CompanyID=SPWR&mobileid= |title=Spwr - Nasdaq |website=Investors.sunpowercorp.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-24}} where Dinwoodie served as CEO and later CTO for the subsidiary, SunPower Corporation, Systems.{{cite web|url=http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2011/06/09/241120/solar-is-ready-now-%E2%80%9Cferocious-cost-reductions-make-solar-pv-competitive/ |title=ThinkProgress |publisher=ThinkProgress |date= |accessdate=2017-02-24}} SunPower produces high-efficiency solar cells and modules.{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/eastbay/stories/2006/11/20/story4.html?b=1163998800%25255E1378066 |title=SunPower acquires PowerLight |website=Bizjournals.com |accessdate=2017-02-24}} Dinwoodie holds over 30 patents on PV-related products.{{cite web|url=http://patents.justia.com/inventor/tom-dinwoodie |title=Patents by Inventor Tom Dinwoodie |website=Patents.justia.com |accessdate=2017-02-24}} == Education == Dinwoodie holds a BS in Civil and Environmental Engineering from [[Cornell University]],{{cite web|url=http://www.alumni.cornell.edu/csv/csv10/csv10-dinwoodie.cfm |title=Cornell Silicon Valley |website=Alumni.cornell.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-02-24}} an MS from the Department of Mechanical Engineering from [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]], and an MArch in Architecture from the [[University of California, Berkeley|University of California at Berkeley]]. == Current business initiatives == Dinwoodie is Executive Producer of ''Time to Choose'', a film by [[Charles Ferguson (filmmaker)|Charles Ferguson]] that seeks to raise awareness of the causes of, and solutions to, climate change. The film released in June, 2016. Dinwoodie is or has been an advisor to, Board Member, seed investor or founder of a range of clean-tech startups, spanning wind and solar technologies, electric transportation, off-grid micropower, financial services, and clean utilities. These companies include AllPower Labs, Ethical Electric, Etrion Corporation, Fenix Int’l, Keystone Tower Systems, Mosaic, MyDomino, NEW GmbH, NEXTracker, PowerLight, SCOOT, Sistine Solar, Sungevity, SunPower Systems,Solar Grid Storage, and TDEnergy.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/uciliawang/2014/07/24/solar-startup-mosaic-counts-on-former-sunpower-exec-for-growth/|title=Solar Startup Mosaic Counts On Former SunPower Exec For Growth|first=Ucilia|last=Wang|publisher=}}{{cite web|last=Baker |first=David R. |url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Meet-the-Berkeley-burners-trying-to-hack-climate-6662070.php |title=Meet the Berkeley burners trying to hack climate change |website=Sfchronicle.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-24}} Dinwoodie serves as Lead Independent Trustee of the [[Rocky Mountain Institute]], a nonprofit think-and-do tank focused on solutions for the transition to a clean energy economy. He also serves on the Sierra Club's Climate Cabinet and Scientific Advisory Panel, the MIT Mechanical Engineering Visiting Committee, and the Advisory Board to The Solutions Project, and is an Advisor to the MIT Energy Club. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.timetochoose.com Timetochoose.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Dinwoodie, Tom}} [[Category:Climate change environmentalists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sustainability advocates]] [[Category:Cornell University alumni]] [[Category:American chief executives]] [[Category:People associated with energy]] [[Category:Appropriate technology advocates]] [[Category:Green thinkers]] [[Category:People associated with solar power]] [[Category:21st-century American businesspeople]] [[Category:Environmental ethics]] [[Category:1954 births]]

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/110.20.219.46|110.20.219.46]] to version by Victor Schmidt. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3548496) (Bot)
revision.text:
[[file:Greek - Procession of Twelve Gods and Goddesses - Walters 2340.jpg|thumb|upright=1.8|Fragment of a [[Hellenistic]] [[relief sculpture|relief]] (1st century BC{{endash}}1st century AD) depicting the twelve Olympians carrying their attributes in procession; from left to right, Hestia (scepter), Hermes (winged cap and staff), Aphrodite (veiled), Ares (helmet and spear), Demeter (scepter and wheat sheaf), Hephaestus (staff), Hera (scepter), Poseidon (trident), Athena (owl and helmet), Zeus (thunderbolt and staff), Artemis (bow and quiver), Apollo (lyre), from the [[Walters Art Museum]].[[Walters Art Museum]], [http://art.thewalters.org/detail/38764 accession number 23.40].]] In [[ancient Greek religion]] and [[Greek mythology|mythology]], the '''twelve Olympians''' are the major deities of the [[Greek mythology|Greek]] [[Pantheon (gods)|pantheon]], commonly considered to be [[Zeus]], [[Hera]], [[Poseidon]], [[Demeter]], [[Athena]], [[Apollo]], [[Artemis]], [[Ares]], [[Aphrodite]], [[Hephaestus]], [[Hermes]], and either [[Hestia]] or [[Dionysus]].Hansen, [https://books.google.com/books?id=a-NmaO-kM2UC&pg=PA250 p. 250]; Burkert, pp. 125 ff.; Dowden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA43 p. 43]; Chadwick, [https://books.google.com/books?id=RMj7M_tGaNMC&pg=PA85 p. 85]; Müller, [https://books.google.com/books?id=qoIOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA419 pp. 419 ff.]; Pache, [https://books.google.com/books?id=lNV6-HsUppsC&pg=RA2-PA308 pp. 308 ff.]; Thomas, [https://books.google.com/books?id=9CUxDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT35 p. 12]; Shapiro, [https://books.google.com/books?id=7q1LDrb9btkC&pg=PT362 p. 362]; Long, [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA140 pp. 140–141]; Morford, p. 113; Hard [https://books.google.com/books?id=r1Y3xZWVlnIC&pg=PA80 p. 80]. They were called 'Olympians' because, according to tradition, they resided on [[Mount Olympus]]. Although [[Hades]] was a major ancient Greek god, and was the brother of the first generation of Olympians (Zeus, Poseidon, Hera, Demeter, and Hestia), he resided in the [[Greek underworld|underworld]], far from Olympus, and thus was not usually considered to be one of the Olympians. Besides the twelve Olympians, there were many other cultic groupings of twelve gods. ==Olympians== The Olympians were a race of [[deity|deities]], primarily consisting of a third and fourth generation of immortal beings, worshipped as the principal gods of the Greek [[pantheon (gods)|pantheon]] and so named because of their residency atop [[Mount Olympus]]. They gained their supremacy in a ten-year-long [[Titanomachy|war of gods]], in which Zeus led his siblings to victory over the previous generation of ruling gods, the [[Titan (mythology)|Titans]]. They were a family of gods, the most important consisting of the first generation of Olympians, offspring of the Titans [[Cronus]] and [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]]: [[Zeus]], [[Poseidon]], [[Hera]], [[Demeter]] and [[Hestia]], along with the principal offspring of Zeus: [[Athena]], [[Apollo]], [[Artemis]], [[Ares]], [[Aphrodite]],According to [[Homer]], Aphrodite was the daughter of Zeus (''[[Iliad]]'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng1:3.374 3.374], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng1:20.105 20.105]; ''[[Odyssey]]'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-eng1:8.308 8.308], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-eng1:8.320 320]) and Dione (''[[Iliad]]'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng1:5.370 5.370–71]), see Gantz, pp. 99–100. However, According to [[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+183 183–200], Aphrodite was born from Uranus' severed genitals, see Gantz, pp. 99–100. [[Hephaestus]], [[Hermes]], and [[Dionysus]]. Although [[Hades]] was a major deity in the Greek [[Pantheon (religion)|pantheon]], and was the brother of Zeus and the other first generation of Olympians, his realm was far away from Olympus in the [[Greek underworld|underworld]], and thus he was not usually considered to be one of the Olympians.Hansen, [https://books.google.com/books?id=a-NmaO-kM2UC&pg=PA250 p. 250]; Morford, p. 113; Hard [https://books.google.com/books?id=r1Y3xZWVlnIC&pg=PA80 p. 80]. Olympic gods can be contrasted to [[chthonic]] godsChadwick, [https://books.google.com/books?id=RMj7M_tGaNMC&pg=PA85 p. 85]. including Hades, by mode of sacrifice, the latter receiving sacrifices in a ''[[bothros]]'' (βόθρος, "pit") or ''[[megaron]]'' (μέγαρον, "sunken chamber")Dillon, [https://books.google.com/books?id=A4YyVL0sygAC&pg=PA114 p. 114]. rather than at an altar. The canonical number of Olympian gods was twelve, but besides the (thirteen) principal Olympians listed above, there were many other residents of Olympus, who thus might be called Olympians.Ogden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA2, pp. 2–3]; Dowden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA43 p. 43]; Hansen, [https://books.google.com/books?id=a-NmaO-kM2UC&pg=PA250 p. 250]; Burkert, p. 125. [[Heracles]] became a resident of Olympus after his [[apotheosis]] and married another Olympian resident [[Hebe (mythology)|Hebe]].[[Herodotus]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0126%3Abook%3D2%3Achapter%3D43 2.43–44]. Some others who might be considered Olympians, include: the [[Muses]], the [[Graces]], [[Iris (mythology)|Iris]], [[Dione (Titaness)|Dione]], [[Eileithyia]], the [[Horae]], and [[Ganymede (mythology)|Ganymede]].Just who might be called an Olympian is not entirely clear. For example Dowden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA43 p. 43], describes Heracles, Hebe, the Muses, and the Graces as Olympians, and on [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA45 p. 45], lists Iris, Dione, and Eileithyia among the Homeric Olympians, while Hansen, [https://books.google.com/books?id=a-NmaO-kM2UC&pg=PA250 p. 250], describes Heracles, Hebe, the Horae, and Ganymede as notable residents of Olympus, but says they "are not ordinarily classified as Olympians". ==Twelve gods== Besides the twelve Olympians, there were many other various cultic groupings of twelve gods throughout ancient Greece. The earliest evidence of Greek religious practice involving twelve gods ([[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: δωδεκάθεον, ''dodekatheon'', from δώδεκα ''dōdeka'', "twelve" and θεοί ''theoi'', "gods") comes no earlier than the late sixth century BC.Dowden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA43 p. 43]; Rutherford, p. 43;. According to [[Thucydides]], an [[Altar of the Twelve Gods|altar of the twelve gods]] was established in the [[agora]] of [[Ancient Athens|Athens]] by the [[archon]] Pisistratus (son of [[Hippias (tyrant)|Hippias]], and the grandson of the tyrant [[Pisistratus]]), in c. 522 BC.Rutherford, pp. 43–44; [[Thucydides]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0105%3Abook%3D6%3Achapter%3D54 6.54.6-7]. The altar became the central point from which distances from Athens were measured and a place of supplication and refuge.Gadbery, p. 447. [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]] apparently also had an early tradition of twelve gods.Dowden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA43 p. 43]; Rutherford, p. 44; Long, pp. 58–62 (T 13), 154–157. The ''[[Homeric Hymns|Homeric Hymn to Hermes]]'' (c. 500 BC) has the god [[Hermes]] divide a sacrifice of two cows he has stolen from Apollo, into twelve parts, on the banks of the river [[Alfeios|Alpheius]] (presumably at Olympia): :"Next glad-hearted Hermes dragged the rich meats he had prepared and put them on a smooth, flat stone, and divided them into twelve portions distributed by lot, making each portion wholly honorable."Long, pp. 61–62 (T 13 G), 156–157; ''[[Homeric Hymns|Homeric Hymn to Hermes]]'', [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text;jsessionid=D804873CE4D29E774667567AC3A6A3E0?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0138%3Ahymn%3D4%3Acard%3D94 128–129]. Pindar, in an ode written to be sung at Olympia c. 480 BC, has [[Heracles]] sacrificing, alongside the Alpheius, to the "twelve ruling gods":Dowden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA43 p. 43]; Rutherford, p. 44; Long, pp. 59–60 (T 13 C), 154–155. :"He [Heracles] enclosed the [[Altis]] all around and marked it off in the open, and he made the encircling area a resting-place for feasting, honoring the stream of the Alpheus along with the twelve ruling gods."[[Pindar]], ''Olympian'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0162%3Abook%3DO.%3Apoem%3D10 10.49]. Another of Pindar's Olympian odes mentions "six double altars".Rutherford, p. 44; Long, pp. 58 (T 13 A), 154; [[Pindar]], ''Olympian'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0033.tlg001.perseus-eng1:5 5.5]. [[Herodorus of Heraclea]] (c. 400 BC) also has Heracles founding a shrine at Olympia, with six pairs of gods, each pair sharing a single altar.Dowden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA43 p. 43]; Rutherford, p. 47; Long, pp. 58–59 (T 13 B), 154; ''FGrH'' 31 F34a-b. Many other places had cults of the twelve gods, including [[Delos]], [[Chalcedon]], [[Magnesia on the Maeander]], and [[Leontinoi]] in [[Sicily]].Rutherford, p. 45; Delos: Long, pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA11 11], [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA87 87–90] (T 26), [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA182 182]; Chaledon: Long, pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA56 56]–[https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA57 57] (T 11 D), [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA217 217]–[https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA218 218]; Magnesia on the Maeander: Long, [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA53 pp. 53–54] (T 7), [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA221 221]–[https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA223 223]; Leontinoi: Long, pp. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA95 95]–[https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA96 96] (T 32), [https://books.google.com/books?id=3dUUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA157 p. 157]. As with the twelve Olympians, although the number of gods was fixed at twelve, the membership varied.Long, pp. 360–361, lists 54 Greek (and Roman) gods, including the thirteen Olympians mentioed above, who have been identified as members of one or more cultic groupings of twelve gods. While the majority of the gods included as members of these other cults of twelve gods were Olympians, non-Olympians were also sometimes included. For example, Herodorus of Heraclea identified the six pairs of gods at Olympia as: Zeus and Poseidon, Hera and Athena, Hermes and Apollo, the Graces and Dionysus, Artemis and [[Alpheus (deity)|Alpheus]], and [[Cronus]] and [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]].Dowden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yOQtHNJJU9UC&pg=PA43 p. 43]; Rutherford, p. 47; Hard, [https://books.google.com/books?id=r1Y3xZWVlnIC&pg=PA81 p. 81]; Long, pp. 58–59 (T 13 B), 141, 154; ''FGrH'' 31 F34a-b. Thus while this list includes the eight Olympians: Zeus, Poseidon, Hera, Athena, Hermes, Apollo, Artemis, and Dionysus, it also contains three clear non-Olympians: the Titan parents of the first generation of Olympians, Cronus and Rhea, and the river god Alpheius, with the status of the Graces (here apparently counted as one god) being unclear. [[Plato]] connected "twelve gods" with the twelve months, and implies that he considered [[Pluto (mythology)#In Greek literature and philosophy|Pluto]] one of the twelve in proposing that the final month be devoted to him and the spirits of the dead.Rutherford, pp. 45–46; [[Plato]], ''[[Laws (Plato)|The Laws]]'' 828 [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0166%3Abook%3D8%3Asection%3D828b b-d] The Roman poet [[Ennius]] gives the [[interpretatio graeca|Roman equivalents]] (the ''[[Dii Consentes]]'') as six male-female complements,{{cite encyclopedia|title=Greek mythology|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia Americana|year=1993|volume=13|page=431}} preserving the place of [[Vesta (mythology)|Vesta]] (Greek Hestia), who played a crucial role in [[Religion in ancient Rome|Roman religion]] as a state goddess maintained by the [[Vestals]]. ==List== There is no single canonical list of the twelve Olympian gods. The thirteen gods and goddesses most commonly considered to be one of the twelve Olympians are listed below. {| class="wikitable" ! style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;white-space:nowrap;"|Greek!! style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;white-space:nowrap;" |Roman!! style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;white-space:nowrap;" |Image!!style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;white-space:nowrap;"|Functions and attributes |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Zeus]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]] || [[File:Jupiter Smyrna Louvre Ma13.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |King of the gods and ruler of [[Mount Olympus]]; god of the sky, lightning, thunder, law, order and justice. Youngest child of the Titans Cronus and Rhea. Symbols include the thunderbolt, eagle, oak tree, lion, scepter, and scales. Brother and husband of Hera, although he had many lovers, also brother of Poseidon, Hades, Demeter, and Hestia. |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Hera]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Juno (mythology)|Juno]] || [[File:Hera Campana Louvre Ma2283.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |Queen of the gods and the goddess of marriage, women, childbirth and family. Symbols include the peacock, cuckoo, and cow. Youngest daughter of Cronus and Rhea. Wife and sister of Zeus. Being the goddess of marriage, she frequently tried to get revenge on Zeus' lovers and their children. |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Poseidon]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]] || [[File:0036MAN Poseidon.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |God of the seas, water, storms, hurricanes, earthquakes and horses. Symbols include the horse, bull, dolphin, and trident. Middle son of Cronus and Rhea. Brother of Zeus and Hades. Married to the [[Nereid]] [[Amphitrite]], although, like most male Greek gods, he had many lovers. |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Demeter]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Ceres (mythology)|Ceres]] || [[File:Demeter Altemps Inv8546.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |Goddess of the harvest, fertility, agriculture, nature and the seasons. Who presided over [[grains]] and the [[fertility]] of the earth. Symbols include the poppy, wheat, torch, cornucopia, and pig. Middle daughter of Cronus and Rhea. Also the lover of Zeus and Poseidon, and the mother of Persephone. |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Athena]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Minerva]] || [[File:Mattei Athena Louvre Ma530 n2.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |Goddess of wisdom, knowledge, reason, intelligent activity, literature, handicrafts, science, defense and strategic warfare. Symbols include the owl and the olive tree. Daughter of Zeus and the [[Oceanid]] [[Metis (mythology)|Metis]], she rose from her father's head fully grown and in full battle armor. |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Apollo]]/
Apollon{{ref label|apoll|A|^}} || style="padding-left:1em;"|Apollo{{ref label|apoll|A|^}}|| [[File:Apollo of the Belvedere.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |God of light, the sun, [[Oracle|prophecy]], [[philosophy]], truth, inspiration, poetry, music, arts, medicine, healing, and plague. Symbols include the sun, lyre, swan, and mouse. Son of Zeus and Leto, and twin brother of Artemis. |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Artemis]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Diana (mythology)|Diana]] || [[File:Diane de Versailles Leochares.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |Goddess of the hunt, the wilderness, virginity, the moon, archery, childbirth, protection and plague. Symbols include the moon, horse, deer, hound, she-bear, snake, cypress tree, and bow and arrow. Daughter of Zeus and Leto and twin sister of Apollo. |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Ares]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Mars (mythology)|Mars]] || [[File:Ares Canope Villa Adriana b.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |God of war, violence, bloodshed and manly virtues. Symbols include the boar, serpent, dog, vulture, spear, and shield. Son of Zeus and Hera, all the other gods despised him. His Latin name, Mars, gave us the word "[[wiktionary:martial|martial]]." |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Aphrodite]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] || [[File:NAMA Aphrodite Syracuse.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |Goddess of love, pleasure, passion, procreation, fertility, beauty and desire. Symbols include the dove, bird, apple, bee, swan, [[myrtus|myrtle]], and rose. Daughter of Zeus and the Oceanid Dione, or perhaps born from the sea foam after [[Uranus (mythology)|Uranus]]' semen dripped into the sea after being castrated by his youngest son, [[Cronus]], who then threw his father's genitals into the sea. Married to Hephaestus, although she had many adulterous affairs, most notably with Ares. Her name gave us the word "[[aphrodisiac]]", while her Latin name, Venus, gave us the word "[[venereal]]".{{ref label|gen|B|^}} |- | style="padding-left:0.65em;"|[[Hephaestus]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Vulcan (mythology)|Vulcan]] || [[File:Vulcan Coustou Louvre MR1814.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |Master blacksmith and craftsman of the gods; god of the forge, craftsmanship, invention, fire and volcanoes. Symbols include fire, anvil, axe, donkey, hammer, tongs, and quail. Son of Hera, either by Zeus or alone. Married to Aphrodite, though unlike most divine husbands, he was rarely ever licentious. His Latin name, Vulcan, gave us the word "[[volcano]]." |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Hermes]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]] || [[File:Hermes Ingenui Pio-Clementino Inv544.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |Messenger of the gods; god of travel, commerce, communication, borders, eloquence, diplomacy, thieves and games. Symbols include the [[caduceus]] (staff entwined with two snakes), winged sandals and cap, stork, and tortoise (whose shell he used to invent the lyre). Son of Zeus and the nymph Maia. The second-youngest Olympian, just older than Dionysus. |} Most listings include either one or the other of the following deities as one of the twelve Olympians. {| class="wikitable" ! style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;white-space:nowrap;"|Greek!! style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;white-space:nowrap;" |Roman!! style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;white-space:nowrap;" |Image!!style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;white-space:nowrap;"|Functions and attributes |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Hestia]] || style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Vesta (mythology)|Vesta]] || [[File:Hestia Giustiniani.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |Goddess of the hearth, fire and of the right ordering of domesticity and the family; she was born into the first Olympian generation and was one of the original twelve Olympians. Some lists of the Twelve Olympians omit her in favor of Dionysus, but the speculation that she gave her throne to him in order to keep the peace seems to be modern invention. She is the first child of Cronus and Rhea, eldest sister of Hades, Demeter, Poseidon, Hera, and Zeus. |- | style="padding-left:1em;"|[[Dionysus]] (or
[[Bacchus]]) || style="padding-left:1em;"| [[Bacchus]] || [[File:Dionysos Louvre Ma87 n2.jpg|75px]] || style="padding:0.5em;" |God of wine, the grape vine, fertility, festivity, ecstasy, madness and resurrection. Patron god of the art of [[theatre]]. Symbols include the grapevine, ivy, cup, tiger, panther, leopard, dolphin, goat, and pinecone. Son of Zeus and the mortal Theban princess [[Semele]]. Married to the Cretan princess [[Ariadne]]. The youngest Olympian god, as well as the only one to have a mortal mother. |}
    ;Notes
  1. {{note label|apoll|B|^}} Romans also associated Phoebus with [[Helios]] and the [[sun]] itself,North John A., Beard Mary, Price Simon R.F. "The Religions of Imperial Rome". ''Classical Mythology in English Literature: A Critical Anthology''. (Cambridge University Press, 1998), p.259. {{ISBN|0-521-31682-0}}.Hacklin, Joseph. "The Mythology of Persia". ''Asiatic Mythology'' (Asian Educational Services, 1994), p.38. {{ISBN|81-206-0920-4}}. however, they also used the Greek name ''Apollon'' in a Latinized form ''Apollo''.See, for example, [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses|Met.]]'' I 441, 473, II 454, 543, 598, 612, 641, XII 585, XVIII 174, 715, 631, and others.
  2. {{note label|gen|A|^}} According to an alternate version of her birth, Aphrodite was born of [[Uranus (mythology)|Uranus]], Zeus' grandfather, after [[Cronus]] threw his castrated genitals into the sea. This supports the etymology of her name, "foam-born". As such, Aphrodite would belong to the same generation as Cronus, Zeus' father, and would be Zeus' aunt. ''See [[Aphrodite#Birth|the birth of Aphrodite]]''
==Genealogy== {{chart top|Major Olympians' family tree This chart is based upon [[Hesiod]]'s ''[[Theogony]]'', unless otherwise noted.|collapsed=no}} {{chart/start}} {{chart|}} {{chart| | | | | | | | | | | |URA |y|GAI |URA=[[Uranus (mythology)|Uranus]]|GAI=[[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]]}} {{chart| | | | | | | | | | | | |,|-|^|-|.}} {{chart|URA| | | | | | | | |CRO |y|RHE |URA=Uranus' genitals|CRO=[[Cronus]]|RHE=[[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]]}} {{chart| |!| | |,|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|v|-|^|-|v|-|-|-|v|-|-|-|v|-|-|-|.}} {{chart| |!| |ZEU |V|~|~|y|~|HER | |POS | |HAD | |DEM | |HES |ZEU=[[Zeus|'''ZEUS''']]|HER=[[Hera|'''HERA''']]|POS=[[Poseidon|'''POSEIDON''']]|HAD=[[Hades]]|DEM=[[Demeter|'''DEMETER''']]|HES=[[Hestia|'''HESTIA''']]}} {{chart| |!| | | | |:| |,|^|-|.| |!}} {{chart|border=0| |!| | | | |:| |!| |AAA |!|AAA=     a According to [[Homer]], ''[[Iliad]]'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng1:1.570 1.570–579], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng1:14.338 14.338], ''[[Odyssey]]'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-eng1:8.312 8.312], Hephaestus was apparently the son of Hera and Zeus, see Gantz, p. 74.}} {{chart|border=0| |!| | | | |:| |!| | |!|BBB |BBB=     b According to [[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+927 927–929], Hephaestus was produced by Hera alone, with no father, see Gantz, p. 74.}} {{chart| |!| | | | |:| |!| | |!| |!}} {{chart| |!| | | | |:|ARE | |HEP |HEP=[[Hephaestus|'''HEPHAESTUS''']]|ARE=[[Ares|'''ARES''']]}} {{chart| |!| | | | |D|~|~|~|y|~|~|~|~|MET |MET=[[Metis (mythology)|Metis]]}} {{chart| |!| | | | |:| | |ATH |ATH=[[Athena|'''ATHENA''']] According to [[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+886 886–890], of Zeus' children by his seven wives, Athena was the first to be conceived, but the last to be born; Zeus impregnated Metis then swallowed her, later Zeus himself gave birth to Athena "from his head", see Gantz, pp. 51–52, 83–84.}} {{chart| |!| | | | |D|~|~|~|y|~|~|~|~|LET |LET=[[Leto]]}} {{chart| |!| | | | |:| |,|-|^|-|.}} {{chart| |!| | | | |:|APO | |ART |APO=[[Apollo|'''APOLLO''']]|ART=[[Artemis|'''ARTEMIS''']]}} {{chart| |!| | | | |D|~|~|~|y|~|~|~|~|MAI |MAI=[[Maia (mythology)|Maia]]}} {{chart| |!| | | | |:| | |HER |HER=[[Hermes|'''HERMES''']]}} {{chart| |!| | | | |D|~|~|~|y|~|~|~|~|SEM |SEM=[[Semele]]}} {{chart| |!| | | | |:| | |DIO |DIO=[[Dionysus|'''DIONYSUS''']]}} {{chart| |!| | | | |L|~|~|~|~|y|~|~|~|DIO |DIO=[[Dione (Titaness)|Dione]]}} {{chart|border=0|AAA | | | | | | | |BBB|AAA=    a According to [[Hesiod]], ''[[Theogony]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Hes.+Th.+183 183–200], Aphrodite was born from Uranus' severed genitals, see Gantz, pp. 99–100.|BBB=     b According to [[Homer]], Aphrodite was the daughter of Zeus (''[[Iliad]]'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng1:3.374 3.374], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng1:20.105 20.105]; ''[[Odyssey]]'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-eng1:8.308 8.308], [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-eng1:8.320 320]) and Dione (''[[Iliad]]'' [http://data.perseus.org/citations/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng1:5.370 5.370–71]), see Gantz, pp. 99–100.}} {{chart| |`|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|.| |!}} {{chart| | | | | | | | | |APH |APH=[[Aphrodite|'''APHRODITE''']]}} {{chart/end}} {{chart bottom}} ==See also== {{Portal|Hellenismos}} * [[Dii Consentes]], the Roman equivalent of the twelve Olympians * [[Family tree of the Greek gods]] * ''[[Interpretatio graeca]]'', including a table of mythological equivalents * [[List of Greek mythological characters]] * [[Supreme Council of Ethnikoi Hellenes]] * [[Hellenismos]] * [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==References== * [[Walter Burkert|Burkert, Walter]], ''Greek Religion'', [[Harvard University Press]], 1985. {{ISBN|0-674-36281-0}}. * Chadwick, John, ''The Mycenaean World'', Cambridge University Press, 1976. {{ISBN|9780521290371}}. * Dillon, Matthew, ''Girls and Women in Classical Greek Religion''. {{otherships|USS Flying Fish}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=USS Flying Fish (1838).jpg |Ship caption=The ''Flying Fish'' as drawn by [[Alfred Thomas Agate]] }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=United States |Ship flag={{USN flag|1842}} |Ship name=USS ''Flying Fish'' |Ship namesake=[[Flying Fish]] |Ship ordered= |Ship builder= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched= |Ship acquired=3 August 1838 |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service=12 August 1838 |Ship out of service=February 1842 |Ship struck= |Ship honors= |Ship fate=Sold |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship displacement=96 tons |Ship length={{convert|85|ft|6|in|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|22|ft|6|in|abbr=on}} |Ship draft= |Ship propulsion= |Ship speed= |Ship complement=15 |Ship armament=2 guns |Ship notes= }} |} [[File:USS Flying Fish (1838) in a gale.jpg|thumb|250px|The ''Flying Fish'' in a gale, as drawn by Alfred Thomas Agate]]
'''USS ''Flying Fish''''' (1838), a [[schooner]], was formerly the [[New York City]] [[pilot boat]] ''Independence''. Purchased by the [[United States Navy]] at New York City on 3 August 1838 and upon joining her squadron in [[Hampton Roads]] 12 August 1838 was placed under command of Passed [[Midshipman]] S. R. Knox.
Assigned as a [[Ship's tender|tender]] in the [[United States Exploring Expedition, 1838-1842|U.S. Exploring Expedition]] of 1838–42 commanded by Lieutenant [[Charles Wilkes]], ''Flying Fish'' sailed with her squadron 19 August 1838 to visit [[Madeira]] and [[Rio de Janeiro]] while bound for [[Tierra del Fuego]], where the squadron arrived early in 1839. From this point, the squadron made its first cruises toward the [[Antarctica|Antarctic Continent]], which it was to discover later the same year after surveys among Pacific islands and a visit to [[Australia]].
After the second penetration of the Antarctic, the squadron rendezvoused in [[New Zealand]] in April 1840 to survey Pacific islands northward toward the [[Hawaiian Islands|Hawaiians]], where the ships were repaired late in the year. ''Flying Fish'' sailed with {{USS|Peacock|1828|6}} to resurvey some of the [[Samoan Islands|Samoan]], [[Ellice Islands|Ellice]], [[Gilbert Islands|Kingsmill]], and [[Pescadore Islands]] before joining the main body of the squadron on the northwest coast of America in July 1841. ''Flying Fish'' made surveys in the [[Columbia River]] and around [[Vancouver, Washington|Vancouver]], then proceeded to [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], from which the squadron sailed 1 November for the south Pacific. Arriving in the [[Philippines]] in mid-January 1842 ''Flying Fish'' and the other ships separated to cruise the [[Sulu Sea]]s, then make a planned rendezvous at [[Singapore]] in February.
Found unfit for further service, ''Flying Fish'' was sold there before the squadron sailed for home 26 February.<ref name=Stanton>{{cite book|last1=Stanton|first1=William|title=The Great United States Exploring Expedition|date=1975|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=0520025571|pages=274}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Bombardment of Upolu]] *[[Battle of Drummond's Island]]
== References == {{reflist}} *{{DANFS|http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/f3/flying_fish-i.htm}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Flying Fish (1838)}} [[Category:Schooners of the United States Navy|Flying Fish 1838]] [[Category:Ships of the United States Exploring Expedition]]
